description:
I stumbled across this hidden local restaurant and decided to give it a try.

Easy street parking was a plus. I stepped up to the counter and quickly ordered the Bun Rieu noodle soup. Because it was a beautiful day in that particular micro climate, I sat in their outdoor courtyard patio area. The waiter brought water to my table and then came the big bowl. Very nice flavor and plenty of shrimps and tofu.

I will be back!
author: GARY C.

description:
Funny how this is a Vietnamese restaurant, because we ordered Thai dishes and they were bomb. 

Thai basil chicken aka pad krapow with egg - 4 stars - egg porn, minced flavorful chicken. Gotta get with rice. Dinner portion was huge that we didn't finish. 

Spicy coconut soup aka tom kha - 4.5 stars - BOMB! It doesn't have a strong coconut taste, but it's super flavorful, and you have to get this with rice too. It's not spicy, maybe you can ask to get it more spicy? But this dish is a must. 

Imperial egg rolls - 4 stars - can't go wrong. They come with lettuce and rice noodles too to wrap, fish sauce to dip. 

Atmosphere: casual, order front, and self service. 

Everything was about $38.50 with leftover pad krapow. Not bad
author: Raquel Y.

description:
What happened to the authenticity of Evergreen? The intriguing atmosphere; the fish tanks, the paintings, the stringing lights, the music, the plants, the elaborate menu. The renovation took away everything I loved about Evergreen & if anything added a bit of msg.

The pho has always been satisfying & delicious, sometimes too salty; but I've loved it & it is still in my top 5 favourite pho restaurants in SF. The prices are consistent but I seriously hate the techy style renovation. I miss the old Evergreen!
author: Julian I.

description: You sit down, then you have to get back up and order and pay for your food. Food came out super fast(3-5 mins). Asked for extra forks/ napkins, had to get up and do it ourselves. We have to get water ourselves.
author: Nezelle A.

description: I really really like this place but enough is enough.the last 2 times I came here I'm fishing nats and I don't know what the other bug was out of my pho. Really sad I won't be coming here no more
author: Lorena S.

description:
This is my favorite Vietnamese place in SF. Delicious, fast, self-serve water, and even has outdoor patio seating. 
I like my Asian food with equal parts flavor and efficiency. Cheers to them.
author: C Y.

description:
If there was one thing I took for granted from all of my years working along the Peninsula, it was definitely how easy it was for me to get my regular fix of pho.  With several options nearby, it was just a matter of which one to go to!  Now?  Well, let's just say #worklife ain't about that #pholife.  Which ultimately led me to Evergreen - not a spot I'd been dying to try, but more than willing for pho just a few blocks away!

Stepping inside, Evergreen has a quirky look about it - there's a "main" dining area, some outdoor tables, and then another section of indoor seating on the other side of the patio.  Pretty unique, especially if you want to eat your pho/bun/rice plate outside.  What's more, the menu (which has a lengthy array of Chinese, Vietnamese, and Thai offerings) includes some unique dishes that you don't see often.

-- TAI NAM GAN SACH - Rare Steak, Well-done Flank, Brisket, Tendon, and Tripe with Rice Noodles...$8.75
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/evergreen-garden-restaurant-san-francisco?select=khUq7szaqsXforbAb8uvLA)
While this may have satisfied my cravings, this definitely isn't among the best I've had.  Despite the ratio of noodles to meats being pretty fair, and how the brisket and flank were great, there was only one piece of tendon (booo) and the broth felt really generic. 

-- COM THIT NUONG CHA GIO - BBQ Pork and an Imperial Roll with Steamed Rice, Lettuce, Tomato, Cucumber, Carrot, and Fish Sauce...~$9.50
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/evergreen-garden-restaurant-san-francisco?select=gFlB0TRgS4Sf1oBwFuHBVw)
Much like with the pho, this left me feeling mixed.  The food looked good, the imperial rolls were crunchy and flavorful, and I liked the pickled carrots.  On the other hand, while meaty and seasoned well, the pork was greasy and not exactly plentiful (just a few pieces).  Fine for the most part, but not spectacular.

Beyond the food, service was actually pretty solid.  The workers were attentive and decently friendly when I dined in and rather quick the time I ordered takeout.  Also, while the restaurant itself looks dated and a bit worn, the tables felt surprisingly clean (I have no idea why this even caught my attention).

All in all, for those who live/work in the area, Evergreen is a nice little neighborhood spot that offers something different than what most other places nearby have to offer.  What's more, they did enough to help me scratch my itch for pho.  However, I can't say I'd make it a point to come back.
author: Mike L.

description:
Wow... Evergreen! o.o Initially, the bf and I thought of a dispensary when we heard the name. Haha. And when we pulled up the block, we were like "where's the restaurant ?!"... this place looked like a greenhouse! My party of 3 arrived and was seated in the main dining room. It appears they have 3 different seating areas: one was an outdoor patio kind. The place was spacious! Although a little old looking and the place seemed like it needed a little fix me up, I can tell by the decor and people that this place was authentic and family owned. 

For appetizers, we ordered the lemon rare beef and fried egg rolls to share. The rare beef was fresh and full of flavors from all the toppings: mint, crushed peanuts, lemon juice, fish sauce, and onions. They even gave us an additional nuoc mum sauce to add as much as we want. The egg rolls came in 5 pieces and they were hot and crispy! Delicious and made  to perfection! 

For the pho, the bf and friend got their #1 and it had lots of goodies ranging from brisket, flank, beef balls, tendon, tripe, and rare beef. I ordered #4: pho tai. The broth was delicious, clear, and not salty or MSG-filled. (How I know?? I didn't have to drink hella water after like most places after eating). The slices of beef were tender and not hard to chew whatsoever which I hate. Balanced amount of meat and noodles. They even gave us individually a mini side plate of veggies ! O.o (never seen that before!)  

Service was efficient and attentive. The female server with blond hair was really nice and friendly. She refilled our waters and took away some of our used plates. 

I guess only downside was my Thai tea lacked flavor.. tasted pretty bland and watered down. Other than that, food and service was great. :)
author: Anissa D.

description:
I came here with my Hippo to get dinner. We chose Evergreen because it is dog friendly, they have an outdoor seating inside. We brought our miniature poodle to eat some yummy Vietnamese noodle. 8).

Cha Gio - Deep Fried Imperial Rolls
The way the rolls were wrapped and deep fried was unbelievably delicious and crunchy. This is a must try item 
Tip: If you get a vermicelli bowl + rolls, put the rolls to the side to maintain the awesome texture before pouring their sweet fish sauce.

BBQ Pork Garlic Noodle - [We got chicken instead] - Hippo isn't a big fan of of any other type of meat beside Chicken....and Tiger, Ayyeeeee . 
This is not your usual garlic noodle, it has a unique BBQ/Chow fun taste, which we enjoyed.

Bun - Vermicelli Noodle Bowl - BBQ Pork, this is my go to Vietnamese dish.
The nook mum and vermicelli was so bomb and the pork was juicy and very flavorful. Splashed the hoisin and sriracha now it's game over. 

We ended the night with fried banana ice cream.
Two egg roll shaped fried banana and two scoops of coconut ice cream in the middle. 

Definitely will come by again. 

-BlackTiger415
author: Teason M.

description:
This place has been remodeled recently and they changed their menu and ordering process. The new process is that you order at a counter, get a table number and then seat yourself. The menu has been shortened and the prices are a bit higher than before. Overall it seems like their system needs to work out a few kinks. I was overcharged for an item (the person ringing me up helped to rectify the charge quickly, but I was the one who pointed out the error) and I also had a hard time finding a place to sit with my coworkers because several tables were not bussed. Although we had table numbers we had an incorrect order come to our table and my food took so long to come out my coworker's clay pot had charred rice at the bottom of it (literally black) which we assume is from it sitting too long in the pot. The worst part was that their self serve water station had dirty glasses at it. I picked up a glass from the top of a stack and found lipstick on it.


In terms of food I tried their BBQ Pork Garlic Noodles which were ok. The majority of the Garlic was sitting on the bottom of the plate so the noodles lacked garlic flavor. The BBQ Pork was tasty. 

Overall, I like how the remodel looks, but I think they need more staff to work with their new system. I would give it a few more weeks before trying them again. Hope they're able to work it out!
author: Christine L.

description: This is my neighborhood go to for Pho and I go there all the time, have been going there for 6 years and will keep going for sure, I really don't eat much else off the menu, just Pho, but I love it and the staff are awesome too, it used to be a bit divey and they recently hit it up with some renovations and new decor, the food and service are always the same though, super nice people, preparing and serving delicious home cooked food. Thanks
author: James D.

description:
Lovely family run place. Great price for anywhere but especially for the mission. 

I love the spicy basil chicken, pho and imperial chicken rice plate. 

The decor is dusty and old school but fits the old world charm. ;) especially love the cute Buddha baby monk calendar! Hahaha
author: Xiu L.

description:
Wow, I am impressed with the renovation of this restaurant.

The decor and layout of this establishment has changed for the better. It is much more inviting, feels capacious, and has improved their order process.

Opertations aside, the quality of the food has improved with the structural face-lift. I find the vegetarian noodles in broth to be satifying to the point that not one drop or morsel remains before I vacate my seat.
author: Wendell A.

description:
So grateful this Vietnamese restaurant is only a block away from my office! Fantastic service, the food is stellar and the prices are affordable...OH and the refurbishment turned out beautifully along with the much more simplified menu! Nice out door seating and plenty of indoor tables as well.

Tasty veggie options too, my personal favorite is the veggie pho.

Can't recommend this place highly enough!
author: Heather D.

description: This is one of my fave Vietnamese restaurants in SF! I love the outdoor seating because I have a dog and can bring her with me. The price is really affordable and the pho is great. It's self serve but I kind of like it this way. The renovations have really livened up the place.
author: Janice T.

description: I thought the Claypot was really impressive. Great flavors. The pork and shrimp virtually sing together. Cooked perfectly too. I loved the friendly service from the nice Vietnamese girl who made sure I ordered it with the Friday egg. Supervaluedeal!
author: Ted R.

description:
It's your classic vietnamese restaurant, the food was standard and is what you'd expect from any vietnamese restaurant. I'd say they have less of a selection than other restaurants. It wasn't that busy when we arrived because it's kind of a hole in the wall and from the outside you wouldn't really know it's a restaurant.

I don't think this restaurant is anything special, but if you're craving vietnamese food, this place is a great place to satisfy that hunger.
author: Christopher L.

description: The food is sooo good. It's a nice quiet place to grab food and drinks. I am Vietnamese and the food is truly authentic. I would recommend this place everyone I know.
author: Simon N.

description:
Solid food, a good option if you're in the area. We got the pho tai nam (#7). High meat to noodle ratio, which was nice. Good fat noodle option too. The broth was flavorful and just a bit oily. At 8.75 a bowl I'm definitely not complaining.

Imperial rolls were just okay. They tasted doughy for some reason and we didn't get enough lettuce wrappers. Not too big of a deal but I probably wouldn't order them if I came again.
author: Vanessa S.

description: Always fresh and very tasty. Great place to eat if its your first time eating Vietnamese food.
author: Ronna B.

description: On the outside this place may look strange, but the inside is very spacious and cozy. The stringing lights, the nice big windows and of course good food! You'll find anything to satisfy your Asian food craving.
author: Oxana S.

description: Definitely one of those random finds in the city that surprised me with how good everything is. Their egg rolls were on point (they were the deep fried kind that I love - most Vietnamese restaurants don't really make them like this), and their rare beef salad thing was really good too. The price is on par with what I'd expect from a Vietnamese restaurant also. I was helped by Jay who was very attentive to our needs and provided awesome customer service. Will definitely be coming back with my other friends next time I'm out in the city.
author: Minh-Thao N.

description: Just had there happy hour. Cheap good and delicious. Try there Vietnamese beer. Good.  Will come back to check out more of there menu selection. Friendly staff. Loving there out door and indoor seating.
author: Danny D.

description:
I discovered this place on yelp when my coworker and I wanted pho for lunch on a cold rainy day.  It was extremely packed during lunch but seats free up quickly!

This place had a very authentic feel. Nothing fancy, very ordinary. 
I ordered the Bun Bo Hue because I was craving for something a little spicy. The soup definitely hit the spot, even though the noodles were vermicelli noodles rather than the regular thick Bun Bo Hue noodles.
Also ordered the Vietnamese iced coffee and mannnn... Was it strong!! Definitely woke me up!!

Overall, this place is great considering the location! The workers are also very attentive and prices are reasonable! I'd definitely be back.
author: Leilani Y.

description: As the saying goes, don't judge a book by its cover. Then again when you look inside, you start to realize, is that an outdoor courtyard? Not your typical Vietnamese restaurant. They do have the feel good traditional items on the menu. But they also have other items that might get your attention and have you coming back for more. HINT: try everything! Ok that may be too much but start with the clay pot, then you might not want anything else. Awesome customer service as well. Just an overall great experience. See you soon guys!
author: Dang D.

description: Been coming here for years. The food is good, nothing fancy and the staff are nice.  The best part is that I can bring my dog.  Parking is not bad.
author: Jamie T.

description:
Food: Usually get Pho Bo Vien or the Bun Thit Nuong (Pork and Vermacelli).  The portion size seems a little small but it's a good place if you want something quick and easy.

Service:  The people are very nice here.  

Ambiance:  Definitely a hole in a wall.

Overall:  So I work in the area and the options are pretty limited.  Usually when I am in a jam I come here because it only takes about 5-10 minutes to get the food and it's closest in distance to me.  It's definitely a good option when it's "soupy weather" during those gloomy days.
author: Spencer Q.

description: My spicy beef noodle soup was excellent. The menu was simple, the music was good, service with a smile and a delicious bowl of noodles. What more could I ask?
author: Adam H.

description:
Great value for good Pho!

OK service. The server was good at her job and brought out our food in what must have been seconds after it was ready! My water, on the other hand, was never refilled. For the price I can over look this. 

To start we ordered the Imperial Rolls. They were made fresh and brought out immediately. These things are excellent. Small, crunchy and not too oily. The first thing you notice is that splendid crunch. These were 5 stars no question.

I had the BBQ beef pho and it was good. The meat was delivered on a separate plate next to my bowl with a knife and fork which I guess makes it easy to cut up but I really don't care that much and just dropped it in to my pho. This was a 3.9.

She had the Spicy Lemongrass and was great for her cold. Halfway through her dining experience she looked up and said, "Wow, I can hear again!" She said it was OK but likely wouldn't order it again.

I understand the 3-Star overall rating. It's totally fair. This is a 3-Star experience. Don't expect more. For me though the speed of food getting to our table and quality make it a good 3.6 star experence and we will be back.

This is a total dive.
author: Justin S.

description: Amazing service and even better food. Our server Jay was great and recommended the egg rolls, banh xeo and fried noodles. And I must say, this was hands down the best combo of dishes put together. Coming back next week for sure!
author: Arthur Y.

description: Really enjoyed the meats in the pho I got. Also very good prices. Is it the best pho ever? Probably not. But it'll satisfy me enough.
author: Jen A.

description: Had the #1 and it was okay. Broth was tasty but may have a little more sugar and MSG that I like. Don't get me wrong at all MSG aint bad its delicious but sometimes its a bit much. Overall I would go again. My buddy had the 5 spice chicken at it was PERFECT. As if it were marinaded for days
author: Gary L.

description:
Very homely Vietnamese restaurant that you would expect to find in the suburbs with how spacious and relaxed it is here.  Their pho is top-notch, everything else is decent.

Shrimp Spring Rolls:  3 stars
Comes with thick dark brown peanut dipping sauce, I've had better shrimp though.

Pho:  4.5 stars
Broth is fantastic, noodles are good and beef balls were decent.

Banh Xeo:  3 stars
We got this very impressive-looking crepe but it was a bit too greasy and got soggy easily, and the shrimp in it was not fresh.  This dish came with the lettuce to wrap the crepe in and it was yummy when you ate the whole thing together.

Seafood Crispy Noodles:  3.5 stars
Yummy.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Came in with a group for lunch and got a table right away. The old folks running the place did their best but forgot one of our group members order so she had to eat her food after we were all done with ours. 

I ordered the catfish soup that came in piping hot on a clay pot.  It's a little too sweet for a canh chua and the fish tasted old, too fishy.  May be minor but I noticed that the pineapples are also canned.  

The rest of the gang had rice dishes and pho of course. Nothing to write home about.
author: Naty D.

description:
Food = good.

Gol Cuon shrimp rolls (steamed shrimp wrapped in rice paper with lettuce, bean sprouts rice noodles served peanut seafood sauce) = has perilla, so it's a bit tangy. We skipped the peanut sauce, and they provided fish sauce instead. $6.00

Banh Xeo crepe cake (thin rice flour crepe with bean sprouts, shrimp served with lettuce and fish sauce) = ginormous, refreshing, and hit the spot! We were glad that we didn't order the chicken salad, too. $7.90

Heo Xao Mang (pork sauteed with bamboo shoots, onion, lemongrass and hot spices) = good but we thought it needed more lemongrass. And it wasn't that hot. lol  $8.75

Ga Xao Rau (sizzling beef or pork or chicken simmered in rich gravy, tossed with fresh vegetables) chose chicken (all white meat) = good. Take-out. $8.75

Cha Gio imperial rolls (deep fried rolls stuffed with minced pork, carrot, fungus, taro roots & onion served with fish sauce) =  crispy. Take-out. $6.00

They have an extensive vegetarian section and a small section of Thai dishes, too. 

Seating = plentiful. Indoor and outdoor.

Prices = reasonable. Late lunch for two, plus take out for one came out to $42.00. 

Service = friendly, and somewhat attentive. They can get busy.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Hi Evergreen!

I want to confess something.. you have become.. that place.
You know.. one of those places that I don't particularly desire to go to.. yet because of the lack of options, you have become one of my defaults.

People may wonder why you are located where you are, seemingly in the middle of nowhere, but ah those who work near here know there are a LOT of companies nearby housed in seemingly plain old buildings. 

So here I am with a few "go-to" places. If I can't stand anymore mexican food or sandwiches, you are the place I get my asian fix.

Not saying anything is wrong with that. Your food is pretty decent, some pretty good.

Enough of that though, let's get to the food.
Here are my go-to meals.

- Combination Claypot - Look. I don't care who you are, or what you like. Unless your vegetarian, get this meal. You won't regret it. Eat in though. It comes sizzling out of a stone bowl. no this isn't your typical "claypot" you get at chinese restaurant. Looks stop asking questions and order it, it's got chicken, shrimp, those delicious chinese sausages that I still don't know or care what meat it really is, and bunch of veggies with sizzling rice. Mix it up with sirarcha, hoisen sauce (i also ask for basil) and eat it. man it's so good. THE best thing here. Intrigued? That's right you should be!

- Imperial Chicken - I got this one day.. because i just wanted to try something different. And it was boneless. And.. it was really good. Good enough that I think I ate it 3 times that week. One of those meals that taste really good, but after eating it couple times you sort of not want it anymore because the flavors are a bit strong. Try it if you like chicken dishes.

- Bun - what I get what I want to be a little bit more healthy. Get it with imperial roll too. I prefer chicken.. again to be healthy.

- Pad Thai - standard fare. pretty hefty dish.

- Pho - standard fare.

anyways, i'll probably see you again soon...
interpret my tone anyway you like...
author: Paul L.

description:
I love coming here after climbing. Huge portions. Good prices. Delicious pho.

They're always super fast in coming out with the pho. I usually go near closing, and they bring out the food almost immediately.
author: Susan Z.

description: This spot is super yummy, reasonably priced, the staff was amazing and the music was groovy! I'm pretty picky about my Asian cuisine and they have a sweet balanced fusion of Vietnamese and Thai dishes. all fresh and deelish! I recommend the Spicy Coconut Soup and their Pad Thai is one of the best i've ever had (seriously).  GO EAT!
author: Molly H.

description: I bypassed this place way too many times! The food (fresh, great variety, not just your standards) and service (warm and kind family) are soooo good. This is our new habit.
author: Savannah L.

description: Extremely nice waiters. The food is nice, but not amazing. The basil chicken is tasty.
author: Norcloud S.

description: Great experiences every time I've been here. The most authentic place to get pho in this part of town. Try #18 Bun Rieu, it's really good!
author: Nicole M.

description:
Food 5+
 Basil Chicken and Pho with raw beef are my fav. always satisfying.
Ambiance 3 
Service 4
Price 5+ Everything is under $10.
author: Tory T.

description: If your looking for authentic vietnamese food and don't want to go to the L's this is the place to go. Away from all the crackhead and junkies.... their egg rolls have taro inside....need I say more? I've been coming here since they sold golden flower in c town. I've been eating their food since I was a kid. Same great taste, this place never let's me down. You will find something that will always bring you back like their coffee or raw beef. There's only 3 places in and around sf that have authentic vietnamese food pho2000, ha nam nimh and of course here. Don't let their thai portion of menu throw you off, they're just adapting to this area in which alot of people also request for thai inspired dishes. Which for me don't cut it but than again I don't come here for thai food.
author: Sherwood Y.

description: I love this place... cause they don't give a shit about what anyone on Yelp thinks about them.   They just make great, and inexpensive food.   Ive been eating here since 2001... and I move the place.    The beat up nasty bathrooms, the half dead fish in the tank that's never been cleaned... the staff that hardly speaks English... all of it... its funky atmosphere, sticky menu's, busted up mismatched furniture... and the awesome Mongolian Beef Chow Fun with extra vegetables... for $12!!!   that's both a lunch and a dinner in one.    So Yelp ... and all you Yelpers... You all go go eat dog-shit for all this place cares... cause they will just go on about their day, and make simple, tasty and inexpensive food, without a care in the world about your over entitled opinion.
author: Vlad C.

description: Fast friendly service, reasonable SF prices.  Would recommend for staple Vietnamese food if you're in the area.
author: Ginger S.

description:
THE SITUATION

Craving Vietnamese food but too sickly-lazy to go get it?  

THE COMPROMISE

For ~$30, Evergreen Garden will speedily deliver:  1) Basic Shrimp Spring Rolls accompanied by questionable "peanut sauce," 2) A Decent-but-not-Sunflower Vermicelli Bowl with Grilled Chicken & Shrimp and 3) A Five Spice Chicken Rice plate.

(Actually, Five Spice Chicken Plastic Container is more accurate.)

#GetsTheJobDone
author: Amy C.

description:
Are you looking for somewhat a Vietnamese restaurant that just wants to serve you Vietnamese food? Come to Evergreen. The restaurant is nice enough where it doesn't feel like a hole-in-the-wall, but its without pretense. It just wants have you eat good Vietnamese food.

I was real into the pho, and the spring rolls were great. A good amount of broth that I slurped up, and then drank my friend's too. I don't get why people leave broth over--it's the best part of the soup. Besides the noodles. And the beef. And the string beans. And the basil. Basically, everything is great.
author: Rosy H.

description:
Good pho with good soup. Good sizing with correct meats. And great pricing.

Other pho in SF skim on size, pho clearly wasn't done overnights, or have mostly meatballs for protein, or is weirdly pretentious. 
This is a good go-to for SF. I eat pho a lot in San Jose (which I would rate 5 stars) - but come here if I'm in the city.
author: Andy L.

description: For their bun reiu, I gave it three stars. Service is always very good. They are very nice there. The prices are a bit expensive for San Francisco but I'm sure rent is not cheap either. It has a big patio in the back so it's best for big parties. They charge one dollar per tea which is ridiculous, so I always get hot water with lemon.
author: Emily L.

description: Ordered the pho bo vien. Extremely salty, I can't even taste the flavor. The beef balls are dry and feel almost rubbery. Really wanted to like this place as it is a block from my office.
author: Nehika M.

description: This is a great place to get Vietnamese near the Mission.  I have ate at the actual restaurant a few times but order take out almost weekly from them.  Eating at the restaurant is very nice.  There is an open courtyard with umbrellas to shade from the sun.  They always make sure to keep your water glass full!  The pho is a really nice size with the usual accompaniments.  Some things outside of the norm I like is the number 102 Canh Chua Chay Dau Hu spicy sweet & sour vegetable soup, bean cake cooked with fresh vegetable in spicy and sour broth.  There are huge chunks of tofu, tomatoes, bean sprouts, and pineapple.  It is really good and vegetarian.  I also like the Crispy friend noodles.  I have only got the vegetarian version but they taste great.  Their mock chicken was really amazing too.  Tastes like real chicken, texture and flavor.  Spring rolls for the most part are always fresh.  You can tell by the color of the bean sprouts ;-)  The default sauce is the hoisin, but I always ask for the fish sauce to dip spring rolls, important if you are ordering take out.  They don't really have Tom Yum, they only have Tom Kha, but it definetly tastes different then the Thai version.  A lot redder with chili oil.  They will also put minimal coconut milk in and it tastes just as good.  They serve large dried chilis in it as well.  I also really like how they swipe your card once they get to your door, they don't take it over the phone, I feel a lot more secure this way.  I'm also a fan of their Pad Thai.  Tastes very saucy.
author: Tyler J.

description:
A great no frills neighborhood restaurant! 

Free and fast delivery

The imperial rolls and imperial chicken are delicious and I generally never order chicken!
author: Emily W.

description: A classic hole in the wall place with good food at good prices. I'm vegetarian and I talked with the workers long ago about their excellent yuba-like fake meat and they talked about how much work it was to make it. Its delicious.
author: ari s.

description:
For years, I've had to travel outside my comfort zone, for good Pho. In the past, it meant 4th Ave. & Clement St., a considerable distance across San Francisco. 

Not anymore. The Evergreen Garden has Pho that is both rich, and sweet. A touch spicy, but not too salty. In other words, damn perfect. 

And their location?
A scant (5) blocks from home. 

I will be returning here time & again.
author: Dashiell M.

description: I love this place. The people who run it work incredibly hard and do everything they can to please the customer. They remember your favorites and do special orders and accommodations for any dietary restrictions. I am so glad they are in the neighborhood. They have saved me many a late night and their tofu salad is delicious!
author: Marjorie L.

description:
My boyfriend and I eat here after climbing at Mission Cliffs probably once or twice a month. He always get pho; I always get vermicelli noodles. They are fast and the food is cheap and always tastes amazing. 

However, the real reason I am writing this review is because of their service and staff. Last night, I ordered some food to go and a minute later, realized that I didn't have my wallet with me. When I told them that I had to bike home quickly, they shushed me and told me to just pay next time. Gestures like that build a sense of community, and for that reason alone, I will be a loyal customer. But let's be real--I'm already a loyal customer :)

Thank you so much, Evergreen!
author: Lynne T.

description:
As a self proclaimed Vietnamese cuisine enthusiast, I can say that their imperial pho or Bon  bo hue has one of the most flavorful soup bases I've ever had at a Vietnamese restaurant. The lemongrass was not overpowering and you can request a less spicy option. You also taste subtle sweetness from the red onion - umami anyone? This is the Vietnamese version. I really can't praise the soup enough. 

I'd fly here from NY just for this dish. I told ya, I am obsessed. Super impressive and insanely cheap.
author: Ulla L.

description: I tried pho here , actually, I do t think it's real pho.... Because the soup is just tastes like water...
author: Nancy K.

description: Went there yesterday and was surprised how fast the food came out after I ordered the Mongolian chicken and today I'm sick.  I ate there because I had a meeting across the street and had no time to find something else and boy do I regret it.  I don't write many reviews but have to warn others to watch out because you will get sick eating here.
author: Salmon T.

description:
Craving pho is a syndrome I get whenever I walk through fog during my morning commute. A group of us came here and the place is huge, but they don't have that many people servicing....so it can get pretty crazy. We practically had to seat ourselves, but once that was done....things rolled smoothly. 

Everything was solid, but nothing blew my mind. The imperial rolls here come with extra noodles to wrap and dip, which was a pleasant surprise for me, the carb lover. 

Will probably be back since it's a solid pho place around the area.
author: Annie S.

description:
Coming here for lunch before work. I sought out one of the only places in the district to not be infested by Techies and Snobby looking peninsula people...

 And here I find evergreen Restaurant, Holy crap its Vietnamese..(Standard Bar of expectations increased)

Coming in here through a door and walk way that looks like it has been changed since the air force base across the bay closed down, I figures this is what happened to a neighborhood so compacted by no parking or limited parking on an hourly basis, little of any revenue comes in for the owners here to really renovate the place by any stretch of imagination.

Old tile floors that make you think of tic tacs....an old Pentagon Fish tank so covered in algae, you would think the Algae ate the fish.....man....this place needs an advertisement....but probably not as a Phone place...

I instantly ordered a Pho Tai, but apparently everything here comes in one size....Large... when really when compared to Kevin's noodle house its really a med-small..for 8 bucks...(-1)

Was it worth it? No
Was it heavy with msg? No the broth had no flavor.
 Was the beef actually rare?  No
What did the lady call it when I walked up to pay the bill? Pho Xue La...-_-.....(-2)

Disappointed as well cause they did not have Chao Tom.....diew .......really?? (-1)

Bo Tai Chunh- Rare beef salad with lemon, fish sauce with peanut crumbs and greens....passable... not the best...

BUT unlike some places.. they used 3 Crab Brand Fish Sauce!! (+1).. it worked for this dish

.....thank god they did... cause that squid brand crap would get me sick and make me call the health inspector over here....still not worth a second visit unless I'm stretched for time tho
author: Eric C.

description:
Decided to grab dinner here after work right before this place closed. We found seating quite easily and had to order almost right after we sat down because the kitchen was closing in fifteen minutes.

We ordered a large bowl of pho and the grilled pork chop. The pho broth was really salty and not much else which was really disappointing. The pork chop wasn't too bad but there were a lot of small bones scattered around each piece. 

Didn't have time to grab dessert here since it was closing but 18 bucks for two decent size plates/bowl of food isn't too bad. Just be sure to drink up on a lot of water afterwards.
author: George Z.

description:
Plenty of seats. There's also an "outdoor" area where you can sit if you'd like.

The service was pretty good, although I was a little disappointed by the lack of tea. The pho size was definitely large, but the broth tasted very light--it didn't taste like it was boiled in beef bones overnight, as authentic broths should.

The Cha Gio spring rolls were definitely good, but quite pricey ($6 for 6 small rolls). It tasted really good with the lettuce wraps. Should definitely order it if you stop by.

Overall would have given this place a 3 if the Pho was normal, but it was slightly disappointing given that this is supposed to be the restaurant's specialty. Giving it a 2.
author: Henry L.

description:
This place... is deeeeeeeeeefinitely interesting. 

Viet. Thai. Chinese? Some sort of tri-fusion going on and well, I was down to try it.

Had bo tai chanh (Vietnamese beef carpaccio / raw beef salad whatever you want to call it), bun bo hue (spicy lemongrass beef noodle soup) and ... I think the bun that had grilled pork and cha gio in it. 

Bo tai chanh was DELICIOUS. Hard to screw this up right? I've had nasty bo tai chanh before. 

Bun bo hue is totally not like the traditional way I am used to. Evergreen uses thin vermicelli noodles, not the thicker ones. The seasonings in their BBH all sit on the bottom of the bowl, so be sure to stir it and frequently. I thought it was bland until I got further into my soup and realized it was all down there. There was also no pork blood, sadness. 

The bun dish was mehh okay from what I remember about the few bites I had. Kind of skimp on the meat and the cha gio was forgettable.
author: Susy C.

description: Absolutely phenomenal pho-- best have had in the Bay area. Great place to dine after a climbing session at mission cliffs, which is just across the street.
author: Jake S.

description: I've searched San Francisco far and wide for pho places and I think I finally found it. This place is soooooooooo good! Miss Saigon and Golden Star are always so packed and not that easy to get to during commute hours. I got the number 1 and it was absolutely delicious.   Definitely give this place a shot because the reviews don't do it justice.
author: Rachael L.

description: Best Vietnamese food in mission! Everything is so fresh and they're generous in providing extra vegetables & herbs.
author: Mah N.

description: Nothing beats a warm bowl of pho and imperial rolls after a few hours at the climbing gym next door. Good flavor to the soup,m and reasonable prices!
author: Ray H.

description: Delicious, priced right and convenient. This is close to my gym and makes it easy to get a good meal. Pho and BBQ pork are great.
author: Ron P.

description:
its a decent family owned vietnamese place without the SF prices.  the family who owns this place is nice and the place isnt always packed but seems to get a lot of to go orders. its our new go to place for vietnamese food that won't cost crazy prices or when i don't make pho at home.

i got the bun bo hue and should have stuck with the regular pho.  other than that, i'll be back again.  where else can you go and get a meal for less that $20 for two in SF?!
author: J. T.

description:
I've been here three times now, and this place is totally fine. Middle of the road. Fairly fast, fairly inexpensive, always able to get a table. 

The good: get in, get seated, feed yo'self, get out.
The bad: no frills, don't expect the moon.
author: Amanda B.

description:
I love Evergreen Garden! For me, this is one of the most beautiful restaurants in all of San Francisco! Why? Because it is *so unique*! I remember the days when all the places in SF had their own character - when you were inside some place, you knew it was irreplaceable and its own thing. You knew you were in San Francisco because there were no businesses like the ones here. These days, all the yuppie restaurants seem the same to me, like interchangeable black-and-gray-painted chain outfits that could be in Any Urban City, USA. But Evergreen is a throwback to more creative times in my opinion. It's so memorable  - just the shape of the building alone is unique,  and you have the option of two different dining rooms or the lovely garden patio to choose from. When you walk in, you really feel like you are traveling, like maybe you are in Vietnam or something. It's got a wonderful 1960's - 1970's feel to it actually. There are old tile floors, fish tanks, and, if you're lucky enough to hit the right day, even old Vietnamese violin ballads playing. A real mom and pop feel that is all its own. I just love that. 

The service is also excellent and I have never ever had a bad meal here. Generous portions of delicious food at a very reasonable price (yes, you can have a great lunch for under $10.00). 

If you're someone who misses the old-school places of yesteryear, you will love it here.
author: Heidi-Jane S.

description: I love this place.  Best vietnamese food I know about in the city.  I stop in there sometimes a couple times per week for take out.  I always order bbq pork over rice.  It's the #30.  The meat is well cooked and lean.  They area always nice and smiling as well and their prices are very reasonable.
author: Bradley W.

description:
Dirty restaurant- I would never say hole in a wall because that insinuates a sketch location with amazing food- far from it here.

Meat tasted old- have you ever left meat in the fridge for days/weeks and decided to eat it cold, straight out of the fridge? I swear that is what it was like. 

Fish tanks inside the restaurant- a tank full of goldfish was huge and dirty. Also the water was ORANGE. Literally, orange.
author: Mario M.

description: Really solid Pho and noodles for lunch, this place has been a staple for me and for my colleagues for years. Affordable, quick and delicious, it's a great lunch spot. I recently branched out and had the Hot and Sour soup, which is amazing. It can get a bit crowded at lunch, but you can always take out. The decor is no fuss or pretense, for sure. Makes me feel that I am back in Southeast Asia! Enjoy!
author: Laura F.

description: The imperial rolls here are so good, it makes me overlook almost everything else in the restaurant.   Service can be slow, but the staff is nice.   Cleanliness wise, they can do a better job.  The tables and utensils seem clean, but everything else like the floors/chairs/walls just look dusty and dated. I felt bad for the fishes living in the dirty fish tanks.  Let's focus back on the imperial rolls again. They are really good and different from other viet restaurants because it has taro and water chestnut bits in it.  Order a side order of it, you won't regret it.
author: Ames L.

description: I love this place for their Pho. It's super reasonable, and fast. I have not tried anything else but their pho and this review is exclusively for that item. I had it with egg noodle and I think it was less than $9.00 very satisfying, good sized serving, and efficient service.
author: Gabriel B.

description: Grabbed the #42 (BBQ chicken and imperial rolls over steamed rice) for takeout lunch yesterday, and it was a pretty tasty, relatively inexpensive option in a neighborhood that's a bit lacking in terms of good lunch spots.
author: Jason S.

description: We found it by accident and dropped in because of its vegetarian and vegan dishes. We didn't have high expectations because it doesn't look fancy and because of the vast amount of choice (which usually is an indicator that the ingredients aren't fresh), but oh my god the food was delicious! I've never had such nice Vietnamese food! I can highly recommend the curry dish and the imperial rolls. The service was prompt and friendly, the price was very reasonable.
author: Ashwin K.

description: This place was horrible and service sucked! My husband and I got pho, the broth tasted funny and watered down, noodles tasted soggy and the meat and seafood tasted old. NOTHING tasted fresh. If you want real & yummy pho GO TO THE TENDERLOIN!!!
author: Maylene M.

description:
Hands down best broth in town. Their soups are excellent. Nam is my favorite. Also a big fan of eggplant pork dish. 

One thing to remember is that you always need to ask for the dinner portion. Even at dinner they will bring you the lunch portion unless you ask for the dinner portion. Crazy.

Extremely cheap. Possibly my highest quality to cost ratio in sf.
author: J D.

description: This rating is just for their #41 with grilled pork chop. The pork chop was extremely dried and burnt. Though I was given two big pork chops, only half of each was edible.
author: Margaret R.

description:
This phó changed my life. 

The best I've ever had and not only that the location is perfect- it's cute and quaint and the people are kind.
author: B D.

description:
Great service, super-friendly staff, good food.

I asked for an off-the-menu vegetarian clay-pot, and they readily obliged; my clay-pot came with bok choy, broccoli, tofu, carrots, celery, onions, and green beans. While it tasted good, I'd have been happier if it came with more "sauce" - my clay-pot got very dry very quickly. Portion size: GENEROUS! One clay-pot feeds two or one very hungry person.
author: Divya R.

description:
(See pics)

Review #1084.

This is a spacious Vietnamese (more Chinese style) place with an outdoor seating area.

Pho was good but the broth was on the lighter side. I usually prefer the heavier style.

The clay pot was excellent as the tasty chewy rice that's sticky but can still be spooned at the bottom of the pot was what made it all very memorable. It also had plenty of chicken, Chinese sausage with plenty of sauce in it. I will come back just for this.
author: T L.

description: Idk what is with all the hating. I like this place. Friendly service, fast, and tasty pho. Prices are reasonable and portions are generous!
author: Jessica S.

description:
After the countless times that this place has fed me and all of my loved ones, I owe them a review. This place wins the "all-purpose, everyone can agree to come here" award whenever there's a bunch of friends trying to decide where to go that we will all find something we'll like. It's my neighborhood quick-stop for a bowl of noodles place, the "such a nice day, let's sit in the garden patio" place, the "what, you've never tried Vietnamese food?!?!" place for out-of-towners. It's the "I want Pad Thai and you want Pho" place.

Hard-working, super nice people are running this place. It's time to show them a little love--tip well.
author: Jaina D.

description:
You know what is tasty and refreshing on a hot summer day when you are helping your girlfriend move across the state? Cold rice noodles with thin sliced pieces of pork, my friend. That's what.

Besides being so got dang delicious, they have survived the gentrifiers and their quest to take over my beloved City. So bonus points for that.
author: Sam P.

description: The folks here are really nice. It's severely lacking in ambiance, and while the pho is good it's not the most amazeballs in the world, but it's nearby, the price is right, the folks are nice, and the pho is still damn tasty.
author: Dina G.

description:
I love coming here after the gym because it's so convenient. 

My favorites on the menu are Cha Gio and Bun Rieu.  The cha gio is super crispy and tasty! You have to eat it fresh! And the Bun Rieu is my usual that I get here! it's flavorful... and if you like, you can ask for a side of shrimp paste to make it even more umami! Yum! 

Service is also great.  The owner and the staff are very attentive and they are good people!!
author: Kelly H.

description:
My boyfriend introduced me to Pho. Well I'm completely hooked on this place. We come here at least 3 times a month. Also they have this raw beef appetizer with red onions and it's delicious.
Food is fresh, good friendly service. Give yourself time to find parking. Especially during the weekdays.
author: Antoinette R.

description:
If you're looking for pretty good pho at a cheap/decent price, go here. It's a little hole-in-the-wall-ish, but that's how you know it's legit. 

This place is perfect when I need a pho fix in the middle of the day. I usually order to-go and bring back to my office, but they'll deliver if your order is over $20! Get some people in your office to get on that pho band wagon.
author: Kris I.

description:
I've always looked for some sort of Asian food around the area in which I work. I work in the Mission so I haven't had much luck finding any Vietnamese food that isn't filled with scoops and scoops of MSG or its an Americanized version of Vietnamese food. I believe it was Friday, when my coworker and I were last to go out to eat lunch and she suggested that we go to this place cause its about a 5 minute walk from where we work versus the 15 minute walk we take to eat Americanized Pho at Mau. 

So the ambiance of the place....plain and simple nothing too luxurious. The atmosphere had a very authentic feel almost as if we were going into a family house to eat grandma's homemade pho(no offense intended). The workers seated us right away, and like all Pho places you must try every locations Number 1 on their menu, being their Speciality Pho. 

Like all Specialty Pho's they come with obviously pho on the bottom with beef balls, flank, and all the basic meats that you would find at any other pho place. Well the only way to really identify how great the pho is, is not by what they put in as toppings to compliment the pho, but it's highly rated by the soup base. The soup base of the pho was VERY flavorful, obviously a hint of MSG...I mean who doesn't use MSG these days, but with that note the soup tasted very authentic. You see I scale my pho flavorful strictly by how "dirty" I think it is. Dirty not necessarily means that it can be lethal to your health, but to me dirty helps me identify how authentic the food is and how it can remind someone or place them in the setting of Vietnam where Pho is eaten like rice. The soup was delicious in my opinion, probably not the best i've ever had but definitely a great place to go when you don't have a long lunch. Portion sizes were great, there wasn't too much or too little, it kept me and my co worker energized for the rest of the day without knocking us out midday like all other carbs would do. 

So the 3 star rating strictly comes from the cleanliness of the restaurant. I know I know up in the review I was talking about the term "dirty" and its relation to authenticity, but the cleanliness I am talking about is strictly on utensils. My co worker and I had to switch in and out forks, spoons, and chopsticks if i remember correctly about 3 times to get a set of utensils that didn't have left over food on it. I recommend all people that come here to take some time to wipe down your utensils before using them, cause based off my own personal experience I could have eaten who knows how many days old noodles that were stuck on the utensils. 

Overall, great small place on a cold day for lunch. Very affordable was about $10 a person walking out the door with great portion sizes. Flavor was very rich in the soup and noodles were cooked very well.
author: Allan H.

description: Reliable, tasty, friendly, and on the way home. Note the phone number listed is incorrect. Here's the right one: 415.621.8531.
author: colleen w.

description:
This is my to go lazy day place for when I am too lazy to go get groceries and too lazy to walk too far for take out.  This restaurant is outdated.  I guess the "Garden" part of this restaurant is that they have outdoor seating for when it is nice out.  

I normally get their bun bo hue here.  BUT, the thing you need to know is that it is nothing close to the normal bun bo hue that you get at other restaurants.  The soup base has a spicy lemon grass beef flavor, the noodles are vermicelli, and the meat are thinly sliced beef and beef ball.  It is very different, but I like it.  I have also tried their canh chua ca (sour catfish soup).  It tastes okay, but they package the takeout all into a container with the soup.  Most places pack the meat and veggies separately from the soup.  I feel like reason why they pack it together is because they don't want to give as much, and trying to prevent using another container. :/
author: Lynn L.

description:
Uniquely Delicious!!!  great Vietnamese flavors, wide vegetarian selection, great prices

Definitely our go to place for vietnamese (get the vietnamese crepe, the sweet sour spicy vegetarian soup, and the papaya salad)

Exceptional food. service gets it done, and that's all that matters.
author: Markell M.

description: Mediocre Bun Bo Hue and bad imperial rolls. My standards are higher AND the quality has dropped.
author: Manny F.

description: Paleo tip: try the Pho with veggies instead of noodles. Delicious and can't beat the price!
author: Stephanie D.

description: this place is great.  The food is excellent and the service is good.  It's nice to have a vietnamese restaurant in the neighborhood.
author: Ingrid L.

description: Great pho in a great outdoor garden setting that made it feel all the more authentic. Service was lightning fast even during lunch rush, and getting a seat was easy-peasy on a weekday. Would highly recommend for groups.
author: Gary B.

description: On my top 3 for Pho places in SF. Great broth!!! This kills any Pho resto on Valencia and the mission area - unless you like pho catered to hipsters. Haha.
author: Mark C.

description:
Good lunch at a decent price.

Love the veggie spring roll!

Also like the soy chicken and mixed veggies and the egg plant with the spicy garlic sauce all really good fresh veggies! Service is always fast too.
author: Michael W.

description: Delicious five spice chicken pho and shrimp spring rolls. Everybody was happy with their food. The noodles are excellent! The decor is what you would expect, nothing too nice, but if you're craving Vietnamese food this is a solid place.
author: Natasha F.

description:
5 stars no question. 

This place is close to my apartment and happens to be EXTREMELY good Pho, and I've quite a bit of Pho in my life. Keep in mind I've never had anything on their menu aside from Pho. 

My typical routine is to drive over, hop in and order a #10. I'm back in my car within 5 minutes, and the husband / wife couple that is normal at the front desk during the evenings couldn't be nicer. I always ask for extra hosin and limes and they always ask exactly how many and toss them in the bag no questions, no snide remarks, nothing. 

The reason I bring that last part up is because as most fans of take out asian food know that's a rarity. They usually would try changing an extra dollar or so.
author: Aaron Y.

description: This review is for the service more than the food. Don't get me wrong, the food is good. (They do use MSG, but will leave it out if you ask. I am sensitive to it, so I know they do leave it out when I ask.) it is fast, affordable, and tasty. The service however is great! Not in the way that some people want service where people fall all over you and kiss your ass. It is service in a way that gets you in and out in a timely fashion while being nice. They also remember me which I find refreshing in a neighborhood where new and trendy restaurants crop up every five minutes. I like to try new things, but sometimes the old standbys are the best.
author: K H.

description: One of my favorite places to eat!  Recently moved away from SF, and I miss this place!  Menu item #32 (Rice vermicelli with BBQ pork) is my favorite!  Very good, fresh food!  Great staff!  Good prices!  Makes me want to move back to SF...
author: Scott N.

description:
Over the years it has been very difficult for me to find any pho joint that I didn't at least partially enjoy.  Well, that all ended today what I ordered #15 at Evergreen.
First of all, the noodles tasted as though someone took day old previously cooked, dried out noodles and dropped them into the soup with no thought whatsoever.  Without a doubt the worst noodles I have experienced in a soup.
Secondly, the broth had very little taste.  I am always very much into lapping up the broth after my noodles are gone, but again I was let down.
Finally, the shrimp had a very off putting taste.
Right now, am back in my office experiencing the gut rumbling one typically gets only after a truly bad dining experience.
author: Steve R.

description: Longtime fan of Evergreen Garden. It's in some ways very basic, but always yummy and friendly, and the outdoor seating is great for sunny lunches. Love the shrimp rolls but with fish sauce.
author: C D.

description:
I would've gave a better review except that I also found hair in my pho........when I was almost finished. Maybe it's time for the cooks to wear hairnets eh? Other than that the broth was good, the eggrolls were great (wrapped in wonton wrappers), and the service was great as well. 

I really like the outside seating in the "garden" especially because you don't smell like pho all day after eating it! lol
author: Christina S.

description:
The outdoor garden is a lovely place to have lunch (though the interior could use a face-lift for sure). Their evening delivery minimum is only $20, which is fairly reasonable.

I'm a big fan of the BBQ pork bun cha (vermicelli) with imperial rolls - it's dressed with delicious nuoc cham and full of fresh vegetables. The Pho is also excellent. When I've strayed to far from the place's strength I've been slightly disappointed, but all in all, the friendly staff and reasonable prices make all the difference. The variety of dishes is great, but personally I think the Vietnamese items are the best.
author: Tim T.

description:
Solid Vietnamese food.  

I've had pho and banh xeo.  Both were great, and just like what I've eaten in San Jose.  The banh xeo was a little greasy and HUGE.  Rough taking that to go.  Lol.

The pho is good - the broth is tasty and the noodles were perfectly cooked.  I am so glad this place is so close to my office- I will definitely be back to try the other items on their menu!  (They have an extensive menu, btw!)
author: Cheryl L.

description:
You cannot...let me repeat, CANNOT, go to a Vietnamese restaurant and expect the thai food to be good. There are two things you get here...Bun and Pho. That's it. 
Pho's okay, hell..it's all we got around this area. If you get there early, the broth comes out piping hot, but the broth could use a little more body. Eggrolls and Springrolls are in fact legit here, but I think the Bun (Vermicelli noodles) with grilled pork is on point. 4 stars for the Bun. Service is fast and pay up front for in and out experience.
author: Brian C.

description: Amazing food and lovely staff. The quality of food is always top notch and the staff is super friendly!
author: elly w.

description:
I've been coming here for years for the Pho and have never been disappointed. It's fresh, delicious, and prepared very quickly. I usually get takeout and it's ready within 10 minutes. I'd highly recommend the rare beef Pho.

I've also sat down to eat here a few times and everyone always seems really happy with their dishes. The staff are always reallllly really friendly. And the food is very reasonably priced. The atmosphere is nothing fancy, but who cares, all that matters is the food and service is great.
author: Taylor M.

description:
Ever Green is ever so delicious. One of the many spots in SF where you get great food, great service at an incredible value. 
Recommended dishes: of course Pho but also Bun is ever so delicious too.
author: Marlo M.

description:
This place sucks!

Don't waste your time!!! 

I went there and ordered the basil chicken...and it looked like 4 other people ordered it at the same time. Well, they gave me a huge mountain of rice and maybe a tablespoon full of chicken while others got a regular portion! That's not right! I complained and they acted like they didn't know what I was talking about...

My friend ordered a meat topped noodle dish and said that the meat tasted like it was spoiled! yuck!
author: Yva D.

description: I love this restaurant! Best vegetarian and vegan vietnamese food I have had in SF! Everyone who works at the restaurant is super sweet. The restaurant itself is not the best environment for dining in - feels like a loud cafeteria - so I prefer take out.
author: Jenna L.

description:
Had the shrimp summer rolls and the pho and it was totally decent.

$5.50 for the rolls and it was a huge portion! The dipping sauce was sweet but not peanuty enough--- it was basically hoison sauce with chopped peanuts on top.

All the phos are one price even if they include different things, weird, but handy for servers to remember I'm sure. 

My pho was okay, they gave me a lemon instead of the traditional lime, and the soup was beefy and comforting. Not great but they definitely have the general pho flavor down.

The service I got from a slight Viet woman was very efficient, the kind you'd get from any other Asian resto.
author: Lisa Q.

description:
I've eaten evergreen gardens food twice.  One time at the restaurant and once through delivery.

The first time was at the restaurant and it was good.  I always get the pho ga and it was not the best or most authentic however;  I liked that it was clean tasting and there was no cartilage.  I also appreciated that I didn't get the MSG headache that  have through other places..  I took a menu home with me since they offer free delivery.

Now the second time I ordered delivery.  They told me 30 minutes.  An hour later still no food.  Called back and it was like I never called.  I had to replace my order  and start over again.   They did end up coming pretty quick the second time.  Like 20 minutes.  So I was happy about that.  

Seriously the food is cheap and good.  I'm not sure if the delivery is always like that.  I will definitely try them again and see if they hold true to the 30 minute delivery time.
author: Lauren T.

description:
Disgusting, uncared for, and unclean place, with a very depressed managing team. 1970s old school Vietnamese bland and uninteresting flavors in pretty much every dish! The staff lacks spice in their spirit and the owners (a seemingly disillusioned couple) seem so frustrated with themselves, they just add sadness to the already depressing ambiance. Their prices are very low, reason why customers return, plus it's practically the only restaurant in the area. One good thing, though: their Vietnamese coffee.

Man, they really need to clean that place! It's mighty filthy!! A real downer!
author: Raymond F.

description:
I was pretty excited when I heard that this restaurant serves Vietnamese/Thai/Chinese food. I'm pretty partial to the Japanese/Chinese food restaurants because I get pretty much anything that the family is craving all at the same place.

I read a boatload of the reviews prior to walking over here for lunch. I was craving pho that day, but was discouraged from eating the pho here, and was told that everything else was pretty much good other than the pho. 

It's bikini season so I opted for the som tum with chicken and the cafe sua du.
It was really delicious. Although, the papaya wasn't sour enough(that is totally not in their control so I understand), I will definitely order it again.

I would totally give this restaurant 4 stars for the taste, but I hate dirty restrooms. Sorry about the minus 1 star for cleanliness. Other than my ocd for wanting all restrooms to be super clean, I'd visit here again, and just refrain from using the restroom.
author: Rosie M.

description:
We love this place. The Pho soup, vermicelli noodles and nice plates are good. 

Their service outside is great. Days can be quiet, or super busy, so your wait time varies, like any other place. 

The main reason for this review: One day, one person in our party dropped her watch. An hour later, I called and asked if they had found it, the man on the phone said nothing was found. I ran back there to look for it in our seating area. The lady had found it, placed it in a small bag, with a note in Vietnamese inside saying  "Belongs to the lady that was with the man with military haircut". I thought it was funny, and very honest of them to save it. 

The outdoor seating allows pets, so if you have small pets, they are welcome. (I've seen big dogs too so I guess any size is ok)
author: P. H.

description: Fast and yummy Vietnamese food, PLUS they have this large outdoor area.  We even bring my colleague's dog sometimes, and he gets to sit and chill while we have lunch.  My fave is the clay pot.
author: Kimberly Q.

description: Had the Thit Nuong with extra meat.  Loved it! They offered it unwrapped so I made my rice rolls exactly how I like them. Not to gummy with tons if fish sauce and meat! Then a 'side'  salad of all my leftover greens
author: amy m.

description:
My co-workers and I order from this place for lunch on weekends, and their food never disappoints.  

I've liked everything I've tried thus far: 
Tai Bo Vien (#2)
Shrimp Pad Thai (#110)
Five Spice Chicken (#39)
Imperial Rolls (#19) 

The prices are fair and the delivery is relatively fast.  Our food is always still hot when it arrives, and we have no complaints as of yet!
author: Cora L.

description: I came here many times. Food good. The room itself is cold. If you want something fast to eat, you can't get wrong here.
author: Kira B.

description: Longtime SF fav! Love 'em. Bun, Pho, and eggplant are all great.
author: Gina O.

description:
PHO!!

This place is pretty solid. It's exactly what you get when you want food like this...

Oh yea and you can get anything for take-out. That's cool.
author: Indy N.

description:
EHHH....at least the asian people smile and seem to be pleasant.  It's a quick lunch fix when you're in a hurry....But the Pho isn't that great...

Probably never again.
author: Janet L.

description: Moved back to the area, re-started my climbing gym membership and finally came here for a bite to eat afterward. Ordered the pho gai (chicken pho)...temperature was piping hot just as I like it and flavor was pretty good. Noticed that the noodles seemed as though they were chopped up vs. whole which made things a little less enjoyable. Also the broth was a tad on the salty side (woke up in the middle of the night craving water). Only other comment is it would be nice to have different size pho like most places. However, given the variety that they have on the menu, I think most palates can be satisfied.
author: Christopher W.

description:
Short and sweet: 

The crepe was fantastic. It was a big portion with lots of filling and and super crispy (crispiness lasted a lot longer than other places I've been to).  The bo tai chanh was really good as well.
author: ML N.

description: Found black hair in my spring roll. Then I returned it, they gave me back a "new" order. Found another black hair again. Don't know if they tried to just give me back the same one or that there was multiple hairs in them. All she did was apologize, not even offer it for free or anything complementary. Cheap place but the food wasn't bad, except for the hair.
author: Jacquelyn A.

description:
The exterior goes well with the name of the restraunt. It is surrounded by trees and bushes and it looks almost like a tiny forest. Once you walk in the door, it's a completely different world, the interior design is nothing special and the atmosphere is very casual. 

They have pretty good buisiness and it's just like any other vietnamese restraunts. I don't remember what's on the menu but they have a variety of Pho options and rice plates. They also have appetizes like spring rolls and imperial rolls which are about $5 a plate. This place is pretty decent, and you don't find many asian restaurants around the Mission area so I'd definitely come back when I'm craving shrimp spring rolls with peanut sauce! They're my favorite.
author: Kelly H.

description:
This is the best place for lunch!  

I've dined-in, ordered for delivery and for pick-up.  The food is always consistent.  My favorite is the pho with everything and the pork chop rice plate!  I usually order either one of those with the fresh spring rolls.  Yummm :)

The only reason I took off a star was because of the service.  Sometimes they're nice other times not so nice.  Whatever, it's not that big of a deal.  Another reason I couldn't give them five stars is because sometimes they run out of pork chops.  LOL... that's kinda funny.

This place is yummy and cheap.  Great for lunch :)
author: Alicia A.

description: This place could have been 4 stars but this is the second time I've had to wait a ridiculous amount of time for a simple bowl of pho. (40 minutes) 1 star for you evergreen!
author: Nick K.

description:
Good friendly neighborhood place. There is some outside seating and they let us bring our dog to eat on the patio. The waitress even brought him some water and handfed him a fortune cookie! (He would have given 5 stars, I'm sure). They could use a little bit of a face lift, their curb appeal doesn't exactly draw you in. 

We got some basics, Pho tai, imperial rolls, and vietnamese iced  coffee. All was good, no complaints, nothing to rave about either.

The broth is not heavy as some reviewers have said, not as light as a place like Turtle Tower, but definitely not heavy. 

They were so friendly, I live so closeby, AND they let me bring my poochie so we will be back for sure. 


Nothin' like a bowl of pho to cure a hangover!
author: Claire b.

description:
Went here after a friend recommended it, and have to say I was a little let down. The atmosphere was a kooky array of knick-knacks and old-school traditional aesthetic, which was fine by me. The neighborhood is actually very safe and quiet for the Mission, which was a nice change.

As for the food, I tried a chicken noodle dish I'd never heard of before and was disappointed by bland sauce and a funky chemical-y taste. Not good. Plus, I definitely had some indigestion after dinner and after eating leftovers the next day. Ick! On the other hand, my 2 friends had pad thai and garlic eggplant, both of which were delicious. So maybe I just had bad luck with my menu choice...

I will definitely give it another try when I'm in the area. And Coffee Bar is right down the street!
author: Gwen T.

description:
I've been curious about Evergreen Garden for years and for whatever reason, I've never gone in.  Today, we were looking for lunch on a patio without a wait and landed here.

What a delight!  The patio was lovely and the service was good, but it was really the food that stole the show.

My husband had Pho and I had a vermicelli bowl with BBQ pork.  Everything came heaping with piles of fresh, raw vegetables.  My meal had julienned carrots, cucumbers and shredded cabbage, along with basil chiffonade and sprouts. The quality of the produce was outstanding.  The pork was mouth watering.  Steve's Pho was so tasty, also piled with great veggies and plenty of chicken.  Neither dish was greasy in the slightest.

As the waitress kept bringing dishes to other tables, I must have asked her three times what various items were.  Everything looked so good!  I was so impressed with the flavor and quality.

Lunch for two came to $18.  Evergreen Garden will definitely be in our rotation from now on.

YUM!
author: Amy A.

description:
From the atmosphere to the food, you couldn't be more enchanted. Don't you dare under-estimate the family of sweet, older servers. They do speak english, and they know what they're doing. down to recommendations. I've hardly seen anyone dine inside- their covered garden patio gives so much more ambiance. Although I've only chosen from their Vietnamese menu, (aside from Thai iced tea) I'm sure their Chinese and Thai dishes are more than satisfactory as well. I make it a point to try to try something new each time i return, and I have yet to be even the slightest bit disappointed. One thing that is hard to pass up is the rare lemon beef appetizer. The fried garlic sprinkled on top, along with all the other super fresh ingredients they use, make my eyebrows do a little dance just thinking of it.

At 18th and Treat (just off Harrison) you'll think you've been led astray with the warehouses and parking lots surrounding the block, but it's just a few blocks from the 16th St Bart station. -and they serve beer! *cheers*
author: eVa J.

description:
I love Pho. I don't try to hide my vices. So guess what, if you serve decent Pho in my neighborhood I am coming for you. 

Evergreen garden is very close to my place in Portero Hill and has very compatible hours to my busy schedule. I believe its usually open till about 10pm. 

The decor is pretty tacky. Old asian art, the constant smell of fried food. The scores of affluent white people trying to not be white by visiting this grimey asian eatery. ;) I kid I kid. 

But lets talk about the food. I order my standard Tai Chin with extra order of wontons. Soup is very tasty. I can't say that the veggies are super fresh, but its workable.  Spring rolls and fried egg rolls are very good. I also enjoy the spicey seafood soup. Excellent. 

My friends occasionally go for the 5 spice chicken and other rice dishes. I always take a taste and find the food is yummy. But I'm a noodle slave so I cannot dare order such things. 

The staff is friendly and food is served very quickly.
author: Lawrence S.

description:
I'd give them 3.5 stars. The staff is totally friendly and nice, and don't give me grief for paying for my under $10 lunch with my debit card.

However, I feel like the quality of the pho can be hit or miss. Sometimes it's really good, other times it seems somewhat bland. I've also tried the fish ball noodle soup with egg noodles, the five-spice chicken, and the imperial chicken. The fish ball soup was just ok but the five-spice and imperial chicken dishes were phenomenal.
author: Dani D.

description:
I like that I don't feel like I'm eating in the Mission when I go here (not that I don't love eating out in the Mission). It's quiet, rarely busy, and gets great light.

I like places that can as Top Chef would say - "transport you." Even if it's just with their location.

Evergreen wouldn't exactly be a destination spot for me, but on a slow sunny day if you're already in the Mission and looking for a new Vietnamese place to try - Evergreen is well worth a leisurely stroll to check out.

Sometimes even with empty seats surrounding you, you'll find yourself waiting a little while for your food, but if you have good company with you, or an interesting read, just take the opportunity to soak in the rays and nurse a drink on their patio.
author: Jessica T.

description:
A waft of chlorine stemming from the fountain hits you at the entrance.  Oddly enough, inside had a definite outdoor feel to it.  I'm continually impressed at how seemingly meat-centric restaurants have some great vegetarian options.  While Vietnamese joints usually offer a list of veggie dishes, if not already saturated in it, they typically come with a side of fish sauce...'tis not the case at Evergreen.  Soy sauce is a replacement for many of them.  And along with Golden Era, their veggie pho has been confirmed to indeed be veggie.  

They've also got soy chicken, which was so(y) good and so(y) filling.  As far as the other dishes go, the pho received a stamp of approval by a meat-eating friend.  I'd conclude that it'll suffice for standard Vietnamese fare, but their veg menu is a huge draw.  The service was excellent--staff was not overbearing in the least, but always there when you need them.  

Though advertised as a Vietnamese restaurant, they also have a small menu of Thai food.  Viet veggie options AND Thai?  I think this place was made for me.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
So I have slowly learned that lunch in S.F. is simply $10+ each time. However, it is worth it at Evergreen. I admit the service is okay, not amazing, but not mediocre. The food though...really good. One of the better Pho's for sure - the broth is flavorful, and the noodles aren't mushy...big thumbs up from me. My favorite thing though is that the food ALWAYS comes out PIPING hot....not warm, not hot....burning...fire people. I feel like that never happens (not even with coffee anymore) so it is super refreshing, especially on a cold day.

(Don't forget...Fire)
author: Chia C.

description:
This was my first time for ph. I've been meaning to try ph for ages and this place was delicious. I am told that this is the best place for Vietnamese in San Francisco... 

The imperial rolls were really good too.

The Vietnamese iced coffee was really tasty too, make sure to try it.
author: Russell Allen E.

description: While I was in SF, I think I ate at Evergreen at least every other day.  It was delicious and convenient and economical.  I could also get food for a friend who was gluten free (fresh rolls, fried rice, etc).  It's not always easy to find delicious gluten free food.
author: C M.

description:
I feel bad writing a bad review, but I'm sorry - the pho here was really disappointing.  I love pho, and have never not enjoyed it until today.  The noodles were really stringy and just . . . not good.  Sorry I can't describe it better.  And the broth didn't taste good at all.  Though I couldn't prove it, I'm pretty sure the headache I'm getting is because it had a good deal of MSG.  Then again, MSG usually makes things taste good, right?  So, maybe not.  Also, the service was slow.  The food came out quickly but getting the bill and paying and waiting for change took a really, really long time, and they weren't busy.  Also, isn't $7 a little high for some simple pho at lunchtime?  Maybe I'm just not used to SF prices yet.

food:  substandard
service: nice enough, but slow
price: slightly overpriced
author: Susan D.

description:
2.5 stars, rounded up.

The rounding up is mainly due to the large variety of vegetarian dishes and the fact that they remember to refill your water.

The food is ok, but nothing great.  I like to get the vegetarian spring rolls with peanut sauce, because I love peanut sauce and mint and noodles and tofu.  You get 4 large half-rolls (each half is almost the size of a normal full roll).  My BF has gotten the vegetarian crepe, veggie fried rice, and veggie chow mein, and I've gotten a veg/tofu/noodle dish almost identical to the chow mein but with flat noodles.  The fried rice was relatively flavorless, and the noodle dish wasn't anything to write home about.  (I didn't try the other two).

The service is pretty bad.  I've been there four times.  Once, nobody seated us.  Another time, we didn't get menus.  Another time, we got menus but no one took our order.  And another time, the lady taking our order left to attend to something else in the middle of taking our order and came back a few minutes later to finish.  Hmm.  The guy waiter is decent, as you can catch his eye and he smiles, whereas the two women are... more zombie-ish?  Not a nice thing to say, but it's impossible to get their attention, and they sort of ignore you, and one of them mumbles when she speaks.  

The bathroom is decently clean for such an establishment, and always well stocked.
author: Stacey B.

description:
One of the best places to go after a climb at Mission Rock!

So my friends and I usually end up getting Pho the day after a night of fun while consuming alcomahol... It's the best to rehydrate you, soak up all the booze and give you energy for the rest of the morning/afternoon :o)

And not surprizingly, it's also a great remedy for after climbs since you can carb/protein up and get some water back into you.

Yum!
author: Bryant C.

description:
I'll keep this short.  Very rarely do I leave a restaurant and immediately go onto Yelp to review them... but this is down right necessary.  

Went to this place for the first time for lunch.  It's close enough to the office, so I was initially excited about that.  It's a run down little place, no frills, no fancy anything and definitely no heat (it's 49 degrees here).  I wouldn't be surprised if I saw a roach crawling on the wall... you get the idea.  Customer service is ok - they're hustling to get people seated and food out.  They're terse with words, but pleasant.  The cost of the items are reasonable. 

I would assume that going to a Vietnamese restaurant they would know how to prepare 'bun bo hue' correctly.  Boy... was I wrong.
