They used small vermicelli for the noodles and they used pho beef for the meat.  The broth was disgustingly salty and the whole bowl was full of oil.  I took a picture of it before I started eating and after... it looked almost identical. 

I want to try this place again to see why they had so many customers inside... perhaps something else they serve is actually worth going for?  But it'll be awhile before I step foot in there again....
author: ThaoLinh B.

description:
Partner loves this place! He orders pho all the time but I love their clay pot and today I tried the broccoli and chicken with steamed rice. We always get the imperial rolls as well.

Definitely a great spot in the city. They always refill the glass of water, it's a nice restaurant and when we've gone it hasn't been crazy busy. Definitely decent pricing as well!
author: Matthew H.

description: I crave the pho tai at least twice a week. Fast and delicious.
author: Robert Q.

description: I love this place for simple expected vietnamese food in the neighborhood. I love the pho and the chicken salad. However, I ordered my first Thai dish off their menu the other night and it was very disappointing. I will go back often for the vietnamese, but never again for the thai.
author: Katherine W.

description: Wanted to try this place for a while - solid menu, nothing earth shattering insofar as the food went - very good, just not exceptional (and that is a-ok) - started with calamari which were a bit heavy on breading, however, good flavor.  Then moved to my fav, mixed beef pho with EVERYTHING In it, wide/flat noodles, spiced up with heavy squirts of Siracha, lots of basil, and as many jalapenos as I can get - good Pho, and again, nothing over the top - Turtle Tower is still reining number one for me!!
author: Richard D.

description:
Great Vietnamese food in the Outer Mission. If you're looking for Pho and don't want to drive all the way to Chinatown, Sunset, or Richmond, then the best bet on this side of the city is Evergreen. Their selection is the standard Vietnamese deal. However, it's the broth that makes pho pho-king good. Well, Evergreen's borth is pho-king good... not too salty and loaded with MSG, but not too bland that it's compromising for the Westerners taste buds.

The unique thing about the menu is that there are a lot of non-Vietnamese dishes. There are mostly Thai. We haven't tried the Thai food, but we'd like to keep the reviews at four stars.
author: Kel S.

description: Satisfies the pho' craving but it's just OK.  Don't sit around waiting for your check, just walk up to the cashier and pay.  More seating than you think too since there is an outside area.
author: Durty D.

description:
Mmm. 

After a few unsuccessful attempts to try this restaurant (they are closed Sundays), I was finally able to last night. First of all, the restaurant is really cute and interesting. They have a lot of christmas lights and interesting chandeliers... plus an outdoor patio area that I would love to try sometime.

The service was excellent until it was time to get the bill (why didn't they want us to leave?!).  Even when we said we didn't need more tea or rice, they brought us more... and guess what? We needed it! Very cool.

I dined with three veggies and we all got different dishes - terriyaki "chicken", cashew "chicken" and lemongrass bean-curd. All were delicious. The terriyaki chicken was really well done. It had a really nice glaze and texture to it. The lemongrass bean-curd was my favorite (it usually is) and I will order it again and again.  For an appetizer we got the spring rolls. So good! And the sauce was perfect.

I will definitely come again! Other than one other yummy vietnamese place on Clement whose name escapes me, this is my favorite!
author: Laura V.

description: In a town filled with great food it's hard to stand out sometimes. However Evergreen Garden does just that. It manages to deliver great Pho in a sanctuary like court yard in the mission. My daughter and I come here religiously once a month for a savory and relaxing Pho brunch. If you're looking for linen napkins this is not the place for you. If you are looking for a peaceful garden courtyard to enjoy a lazy Branch and some sunshine come here.
author: Sam L.

description:
Sick and craving soup, review comments might not be a good indicator of actual flavor due to sickness

Delivery min $20 
link to their menu: http://sanfrancisco.menupages.com/restaurants/evergreen-garden/menu

Ordered
1. Xe Lua special combo with rare slices of steak, well done brisket, flank, landon and iripa, w/ beef balls
GOOD- rare beef a little weird, i ate it, let's see if i need to update this review with bad news later

11. Hu Tieu Thap Cam ( Mi ) - Sea Food Noodle Soup shrimp, calamari, scallop, fish balls, crab meat and rice noodles or egg noodles
IN FRIDGE FOR LATER

74. Canh Chua Ca Hay Tom - Catfish or Shrimp Hot & Sour Soup hot & snw catfish or shrimp with bean sprouts, tomato, pineapple, celery (hot)
TRIED SOME- very weird, sweet and hot, in fridge

Person who answered the phone said delivery time was 30min (weekday around 2pm- so not busy) but food didn't come for just over an hour.  Be more accurate with time estimates!
author: Skye W.

description:
So I'm feeling like I'm getting sick and I want some warm brothy soup. Pho oh yes some Pho. Normally we have our go to spots in little Saigon in the TL which never fail but wanted to try some place closer to where we live. We've walked and driven by this place a millions times so decided to finally try it.

Meh. The Pho itself was good. Not spectacular but just ok. Had decent flavor but not that really savory beef flavor that you get from good Pho. We also got the crepe pancake with been sprouts and shrimp. That was kind of a dissapointment. Really not much flavor at all with out the sauce. 

The other thing was I ordered a seafood soup that was just not that good. But the thing that really annoyed me was they weren't able to fit all the soup in one container so they put some of the broth in a regular thin Styrofoam cup with a lid that was open. So what do you think happened? It all freaking spilled out in the bag which I didn't find out until I got home.

So basically half my soup was swimming in the plastic bag. It was just the broth anyways and it wasn't that good anyways.

Pretty much they almost ruined my car and dinner kinda sucked after that. Doubt I'll be going back.
author: Hyung L.

description: It's a little hole in the wall place but the food is really good.  The pho is execellent and you get a lot of food for your money.
author: Mikky T.

description: I had the Pho Tai. Pretty good. I like the atmosphere. It was quick and the server was nice enough. Bill was $7.55.
author: Nomad T.

description:
I have to reiterate-I love Evergreen. So fast, so accurate, so many garnishes. Even if you get delivery, you get it all, every little bean sprout, down to the last detail. 

The one time they brought me someone else's food by accident, they were back in 5 minutes with the right one, still steaming. It usually takes 20 minutes to get our order delivered. 

And talk about cheap! I always beg for for evergreen instead of a $35 pizza. The meat people can get good meat (word of mouth says), and the rest  of us can get a delicious entree that lasts for a few meals. 

Broccoli in the pad thai? That gets my vote.
author: dodie L.

description:
I give Evergreen Garden 3.5 stars . . . why don't they implement a 1/2 star system here on Yelp? Especially for inconsistent people like me who sometimes select 3 and say its 3.5 and sometimes select 4 and say it's 3.5?!? But I digress . . .

Still wasn't feeling 100% so I got the Pho Ga (Chicken Pho). Nothing like a steaming bowl of chicken soup to cleanse the system. I get it without cilantro (I'm one of those "cilantro tastes soapy" people) so I suspiciously eyed these big floating leaves in the soup bowl when it was first brought out. I've gotten the big spiky cilantro-ey stuff at other restaurants before. I'm not sure if it's a cilantro variant or not, but it tastes like it. Luckily these turned out to be pieces of cabbage. Haven't seen that in Pho before, but I need my veggies so munched it down whilst breathing a sigh of relief!!

Broth was tasty. Unlike Sunflower's, it actually had some flavor. And when I mixed it up I could see some bits of garlic settled on the bottom. Yumm!! Just what the doctor ordered!!

Plenty of basil, sprouts, some fresh jalapaneo slices, and a wedge of lime accompany the soup. A little skimpy on the sprouts, The shredded chicken was good. Not as tender as some places, but still above average.

One odd thing. As others have pointed out, they have a small Thai food menu . . . they also have some Chinese dishes on the menu, but that seems less odd to me though getting too multi-cultural on the menu does worry me a bit about doing everything good. 

Whatever, I'll definitely be back with the girlfriend to try some of their other dishes.
author: Andrew C.

description: I love this place. Been coming here for a minute. Best pho in town! I get the pho thai & imperial rolls, with a Vietnamese home brewed iced coffee. Staff is always friendly and super fast!  And there's usually ample off street parking.Go Evergreen!!
author: Nicole B.

description: Found this little place randomly, just stumbled upon it and glad I did! The pho was amazing and had some egg rolls as well which were just as good. The only downfall is the service, definitely have to ask when you need anything. But that didn't change my 5 star rating! The price is good to which is always a plus
author: Maci H.

description:
I love the fact that this place delivers!  There aren't too many places that deliver Pho.  It's awesome!  Especially on rainy nights.

I always order the Pho Ga (chicken soup) and the Imperial Rolls.  But I've also tried the BBQ Pork as well as the Five Spice Chicken and it was pretty tasty.  

Weird though, I'm not quite sure what type of restaurant it actually is... Chinese, Thai or Vietnamese as they seem to have a bit of each on their menu.   :)

Oh well, I'm just glad they deliver and are able to get the front door code right.  

If you're unsure, order the Pho Ga and the Imperial Rolls.
author: Delilah B.

description: Been coming here since forever. I'd say 17-20 years?? I can remember so cleary partying hard and waking up at noon curled up in a ball on my then boyfriend but now husband's couch with a fat hangover.  He'd offer to get me a Pho with lots of lemon, hoisin sauce and that minty leaf that gives it that unique flavor and it would cure my stomach ailments.   I now bring my 2 kids and they enjoy the Pho. that's all they want to eat, dont even bother offering them something else off the menu...unless it's the spring rolls
author: Claudia E.

description:
Two other girlfriends and I went for a casual birthday dinner close to said birthday girl's work.    

I must preface that I love Pho but this place was so unimpressive that I felt kinda gross after having the Bun Rieu.  

The Joint:  MEH.  Clearly and old diner/burger joint converted into a Pho house.  There is a patio that we didn't sit in but it was electric vietnamese green, bonus for authenticity.  The inside of the restaurant was decorated for chinese new year, bonus.  Festive and totally with in the Pho joint standards but it's location made me weary.  It's located in a non-restaurant part of town (no OTHER restaurants to compete with) and very isolated.  So, I decided to look for the most authentic dish on the menu.  

The Food:  ICK.  I ordered the shrimp spring rolls and the bun rieu, the noodle soup with seafood, crab past and tomatoes.  This is my regular dish at other Pho places I haunt.  The shirmp spring rolls were tasteless and the peanutty sauce they served with it was sour.  The rice paper on the out side of the roll was so hard it had obviously been left in the fridge after they made the roll a few hours ago.  The inside consisted of mostly noodles, a piece of lettuce and a sliver (not a half, maybe a quarter) of shrimp.  No mint leaves or basil or anything.  The bun rieu looked right when it came out but it didn't taste right.  It was not flavorful enough, the fish cake and the steamed egg was kinda bland.  The soup had no seafood flavor to it, made my stomach hurt and I ended up unhappy.  Only good thing to comment on was super clean bean sprouts to put in my soup.      

The Service:  OK.  We had to beg for more tea but other than that the service was friendly and punctual.
author: Marie L.

description: I've been going here with my wife for about 5 years. This is my go to lunch spot. In 5 years only got my order wrong once, and they fixed for me. Minus1 star because of dirty bathroom.
author: Carlos M.

description:
I've been ordering from these owners for almost a decade! Since when they originally started out in Chinatown, that was my first taste of PHO! It was excellent and ever since then, I've been hooked on PHO! Of course when I didn't need to go to Chinatown as much, I stopped visiting their restaurant as frequently, and when I did visit the food tasted different, and I never knew why... until 3 years ago when I came to Evergreen Garden for dinner with my family and BAM, I see the same owners from Chinatown!!! Apparently they sold their place in chinatown, and moved here down in the mission instead. Of course I was more excited since its only a few blocks away from my house so I can get my fix of pho almost anytime (except sundays, since they're closed). 

I read a lot of reviews about them using MSG, but honestly... most Asian restaurants cook with MSG, so get over that. Aside from that minor problem, I love the pho here, just wish the portions were a little bit bigger. The sea soup is a must try! The rare lemon grass beef is good as well, so tender... mmm salivating as I'm writing this. haha. Overall I love the pho here and wouldn't want it any other way. It's also one of the better pho places in the mission, and their service is fast. It's a must try if you need your fix of pho and you're in the mission district!
author: Johnson S.

description:
Nice and easy for lunch near my work. I almost always get the Pho Ga, I like how I can put in what I want (how much chicken, noodles, jalapenos, bean sprouts, etc). But does it have MSG? I don't know, but I've gotten headaches the last few times.. which is a little sketchy.

The Spring Rolls are good, but the shrimp ones are better than chicken. The peanut sauce is yummy.

I'm not sure what it's called, but they have an appetizer with deep fried shrimp on a kebab with good sauce.. It is DELICIOUS! I almost ate all of them while out to lunch with coworkers.

All in all, not the best but definitely good!
author: Emily R.

description: Great restaurant for pick up, quick and convenient. I absolutely love their imperial rolls, I can eat it as a meal, and their pho is also on point. Can't go wrong with this place, cheap prices and good vietnamese food!
author: Ganesha B.

description: This place is sooooo solid.  I have had great food here every time I have been.  The spring rolls (both fried and fresh) are outstanding, and the grilled pork is spot on.  There are a lot of Vietnamese restaurants in SF, and this is one of the better ones.
author: schmoo l.

description: I would've liked to try their food as I'm lying here sick in bed, but when I shared my address, he said it was "very far". I tried to explain that it is only 10 blocks, but he wouldn't listen.
author: Jenny R.

description: I eat here about 2-4 times a week. Love their Pho and Bun Reiu. Two Thumbs up!
author: Braden B.

description: My colleague took me to this place.  Their Clay Pot was absolutely amazing!   The service is quick, and the servers are nice.  I will definitely go back for lunch again.
author: Kioko O.

description:
Got delivery here the other day. The last time I came to this place was at least a year and a half ago.

Ordering was pleasant and the delivery guy was very very nice. I like nice people on the phone and nice delivery guys!

I got the pho with rare beef, which had a lot of food in it but wasn't as good as I remembered in terms of flavor. It didn't help that there was also a strand of hair in it. Sadface.

I also got the fried shrimp stuff which I assume would taste better at the restaurant because it doesn't sit in a plastic container and get soggy.

Lastly, got the fried rice, which was kind of bland. At least I had lunch for work the next day!

So yes, I ordered a pho, shrimp, and fried rice for dinner--all for myself. They have a $20 minimum for delivery.

Anyhow, this isn't my favorite pho place anymore, not because of my particular experience here, but because I've found other places I'd prefer to go to that have flavors that I prefer. Maybe I'll come back one day.
author: Angela H.

description:
This is a great spot for lunch... its always busy (but not too busy where you would get bad service).  

The food is fantastic (i am a fan of their noodle dishes) and its a great deal. The portions are perfect size and cheap.  

Check it out for yourselves... I am a fan =:0)
author: Lila R.

description:
The staff here is amazing, their food is great, and it's never too crowded. Nothin' too fancy, but cheap as fuuuu

THANKS EVERGREEN FOR HAVING A DOPE STAFF! (Lin is my favorite waitress in the city hands down)
author: Kat H.

description: Best vegetarian Vietnamese plates I've had in the city. Had the Curried soy chicken - huge slab of delicious fake meat with incredibly delectable curry sauce and veggies, and the Eggplant Tofu stir fry. Fantastic and not pricey, so I'll be going back!
author: Nicholas H.

description:
Gotten takeout here a few times for lunch and am a big fan of their Pho Ga (chicken soup). To-Go service is usually very nice and efficient, staff are always very friendly. Food is fairly priced for the portions you get,  and everything I've gotten has been very tasty!

As a gluten-free eater, this place is a bit of a godsend as well, most of the dishes have rice noodles or can be modified if you ask.
author: Erik H.

description: This place I have wanted to try since skating past it last yr. Today I finally took my hunger games to the next level. Got two appetizers, beef pho and bbq pork Vermicilli and a Thai iced tea. Was a hearty amount for the price. They forgot my iced tea at first but no biggie. This place is definitely worth it. Will be back for years to come.
author: Mr. Potato G.

description:
Stopped by for Pho rare beef and beefballs $6.95

Not the best Pho.  The broth was not super beefy but rather peppery.  The rare slices were tough and thick but not too many pieces.  The balls were whole not cut in half.  The noodles didnt taste fresh, they were sticky together and when separated the noodles seemed to break.  Service was non-existent but it was noon so they were pretty busy.
author: May M.

description: Loved the food, the Xe Lua was delicous... why choose when u can have it all in one bowl!
author: Jo A.

description: Had their pad thai and pho. The pad thai was a little off... couldn't really put my finger on it. The pho was alright too the broth could of had a little more flavor to it but it was good enough. It was a nice establishment and the people in there were nice. Also, wicked fast service so we were in and out of there fast and we sat down!
author: Tina D.

description:
This is my go-to spot for lunch, since my office is like, right there.

Evergreen makes one of my favorite lunch dishes - I call in and pick-up the bun #30 with grilled chicken. It's delicious every time and so colorful and flavorful. In addition to what they normally put in, including vermicelli rice noodles, lettuce, cucumber, pickled carrots, and bean sprouts, you get 3 grilled shrimp, 2 imperial rolls and your choice of grilled meat. For $9 including tax, it's plenty of food and so tasty. 

People complain about MSG, but I grew up having it in my food and I'm of the belief that it brings out the deliciousness of various dishes.  So I don't mind having a little now and then.
author: vira k.

description: I came here with my friend one Saturday night after our yoga class down the street (Get your Vinyasa on at Yoga Mayu on Harrison and 16th y'all!) . My friend and I both ordered the pho and imperial rolls. My friend is actually allergic to peanuts and there were peanuts sprinkled over the imperial roll plate. We didn't know until the plate came.  He told her about the allergy and the waitress was so nice and she promptly changed the order without nuts. (But I wasn't going to let the first order go to waste! I kept it for myself) the portions were ginormous and filling. I will definitely come again, maybe while running errands in Portrero Hill or after the gym or yoga.
author: Patricia M.

description:
I used to be a regular here.  I don't go as often mostly because the last several times that I've gone out for pho I was in the sunset district and there are many fine options over there.  
Anyway, this place is great.  Quick and attentive service, great pho, and large portions.  I personally hate my pho soup to have blotches of fat and oil floating on the surface and this place does not have that issue so it's perfect for me : ).
author: Amber R.

description: Looking for a pick-me-up when you're sick? After a late night? Or maybe just for a chilly SF day? Pho is a great cure all. So when I heard Evergreen delivers I had to give it a try. While it satisfied my pho craving, the broth was on the lighter side and didn't induce the same mouth watering, world rocking, pho-abulous experience as I've experienced elsewhere. After waiting an hour and a half for it to be delivered I had high hopes. $20 is the minimum order so I ordered some other sides like pad thai and shrimp spring rolls.The shrimp and tofu pad thai was dry but it gets points for the tasty fried tofu in it. Although I had confirmed the shrimp rolls a second time on the phone, chicken rolls were delivered instead. Might be worth a visit to their restaurant since the food was decent, but my hunt for good pho place with reliable delivery will continue.
author: Carrie G.

description:
I had Evergreen Garden delivered the other night and the experience was wholly unrewarding:

First- the food was late and the delivery guy had NO CHANGE on him, resulting in gross overtipping on my part.

Second- the combo seafood noodles had a relatively bland sauce and definitely skimped on the seafood and chicken.  The crispy noodles were, however, well-prepared and delivered separately so I could dump the sauce on top at my leasure for maximum crispiness. 

Third- They screwed up the order and gave my co-diner the wrong dish.

Won't be back.  This was my third choice for Vietnamese delivery in the area but the first two places didn't pick up the phone.  Not even fit for a last resort.
author: Eric S.

description:
You have to give it to the TB, he knows his food.

So he keeps saying that he is craving for pho...and although he would ask me time and again what I want to eat...it always ends up the same way...I make him choose the restaurant we go to.

So tonight, we went to this place...when I want my Vietnamese cuisine fix I go to the one by Westlake (if not the one by Chinatown near work). Surprisingly, street parking is easy.

Customer service was efficient and very pleasant. I let the TB order for both of us and he never fails me.

We had Thai iced tea and some fresh spring rolls, several gulps and sips later and were full.

I recommend this place to everyone who is in search of Pho in the Mission District. It worth the trip.
author: Malou C.

description:
-If you're looking for a warm bowl of pho to fill your tummy on a cold SF winter night, this is the place to go pho-sho.  They make a pretty consistently standard bowl of beef-broth pho.  
-I've also tried their shaking beef.  It was juicy albeit (too) lightly seasoned. I would have liked a little more flavor with my beef.
-Their bun bo hue, one of my favorite soups (with lemongrass broth) was surprisingly tasty.  Their biggest faux pas with this dish was that the noodles were the same kind used to make bun rieu. I'm guessing since not that many people order bun bo hue, it doesn't make sense to keep a lot of the thicker noodles in stock just for homesick (read: Milpitas) boys like me.  There was no brisket or congealed blood, nor was there even some steamed pork loaf or gio.  The only thing that would have been recognizable by any vietnamese person was the broth (which I will admit is kinda important). 
-The waitress and the woman who works behind the counter are really nice, though and remember you! :)
author: Ben T.

description:
Went through my reviews and can't believe I forgot to post a review for this!  I always come here for their "spicy sauteed calamari" rice plate. Hubby gets their clay pot which has rice with chinese sausage, shrimp and chicken. Very good food...riceplate wise. The kids have tried their pho, and told us it's about average.  

Parking is kind of tough around here, so either plan to circle a lot or ask them if you can park on their sidewalk in front...
author: cindy c.

description: The pho had more variety of meat in it than other pho places.  The pho was considered good compare to other restaurants i have been to.  The portions are pretty big.  I would give this place 4 stars, because the pho was really satisfying and the meals actually fills you up.
author: Calvin H.

description:
I really want to love this place. It's close to my gym and my home and there is a bit of a lack of pho places in the mission. It's OK, but I'll never grow to love it. Cute inside with plants and random nic-nacs all over the place. 

About the pho itself? The broth is good, doesn't taste MSG-ridden. The noodles are good. The meat was not good. Both of us left most of our meat (we had combos of flank, tripe, tendon, briskit). So that was kind of a downer, but then again, my favorite parts of a good bowl of pho are the broth and noodles and fixins' so I wasn't too bummed.

The shrimp spring rolls were also just ok--not bad at all but nothing special.

The service was excellent.
author: Vicki S.

description:
I love Evergreen for the following reasons:

1) Their vegetable pho
2) Easy parking
3) Really, freakin' nice owners
4) Quick delivery
5) Great prices

I'm the type of person who likes to try new things on the menu each time I go, but I cannot part with the vegetable pho. I add $1 worth of chicken and ask for chicken broth. It's heaven in a bowl.
author: Alyssa T.

description:
One of the things I love about living in San Francisco is having friends who love a restaurant that you've never heard of or seen.  You would think after a while that you would have at least heard of everything, but this place was hidden right under my nose (I work nearby), and now I want to introduce someone else to it.

The food is very good, and the portions are ginormous, especially for the prices.  The service is good.  I can do without the 9-to-5 crowd (from AT&T?) eating lunch here, but they're more annoying to look at than anything else; they're not demanding or rude in a we're-wearing-suits-but-this-is-the-closest-restaurant-to-work kind of way.  I could see that happening, though.
author: John S.

description:
Some things by nature need a sliding scale - restaurants, movies, cheese. I appreciate a fine manchego or gruyere any time, but give me some melted Velveeta in the right context, and you will have unlocked the door to my heart.

I say this because I'm giving Evergreen the same number of stars as I gave Jack Falstaff (which I rated one LESS than In-N-Out burger), and I absolutely LOVED my one meal at Jack Falstaff.

The thing that made me stop at Evergreen the first time was the plentiful parking. The joy this affords in a city like San Francisco cannot be understated.

The second thing I experienced was a very warm greeting from the folks who run the place. A delightful family.

The third thing I found was that I really enjoyed my meal. I had the five spice grilled chicken noodle soup and some imperial rolls 

Side note: Since then, I've stopped by for a bowl of this every time I've felt a cold coming on. Truly the cure for what ails ya. 

My friend had grilled pork with vermicelli, which was fantastic and not nearly as greasy as I've found similar dishes at other places I like (Tu Lan and Sunflower, for example).

I will say the pho isn't great, which is a small tragedy, since it's the de facto standard by which all Vietnamese restaurants are judged.

It's not a pretty place - although the patio is a plus - but the bottom line is Evergreen gets four stars because you need some solid performers like this on your team. Casual. Close to home. Plentiful parking. Friendly service. Good food at the right price.
author: Shawn S.

description:
I came here on that weird mysterious night in the City where it was 90 degrees at 9 pm and the entire city was teaming in the streets with ecstacy, or drunkeness, whatever.  One of my buds picked me up on her scooter and we were off into the night, in dresses with bare legs, gasp, in San Francisco?

Anyway, true story, we ended up dancing to "RENT" or our version of it under a street lamp across the street from this restaurant, seemed like a good reason to head on in. 

There was NO ONE here when we arrived, but moments later patrons began filtring in.  It was too hot to sit inside so we sat on the patio and enjoyed some beers and vegetarian fare.  My buddy doesn't eat meat so I decided against shoving animal products in my mouth and we split a crunchy noodle dish with veggies on top and "gravy" and a faux chicken curry.  MYYYY it was all very good. And I have to admit that the faux chicken was really really scary in it's chicken likeness, I actually had to keep asking them waiter if it wasn't really just chicken. 

Anywho, perhaps it was the night but I thought this place was really good.  Not amazing, but good, thank Gawd for the Rent style breakdance across the street or we never woulda ended up here.
author: Claire C.

description:
Initially I thought the portions were skimpy for my husband's imperial rolls (5 half finger size). 

I had a really good order of tofu spring rolls.  They were tightly wrapped.  None of this falling apart on you.  None of that soggy rice wrapper either.  I was fairly impressed as I should be since I paid something like six dollars for something I could make myself.

My husband thought the imperial rolls were good and he didn't mind going back there.

Parking was really good on a Sunday at 1:00 pm.

I can't wait to try their combination pho which has the good stuff like tendons--it's harder and harder to find that kind of stuff anymore.  Most of the Vietnamese places I've been to have been cleaned up so that people like my husband from Maine (the good American) wouldn't freak out as I eat.

He always wonders, "where's the good food?"
author: Priscilla L.

description:
It had been four years since I had eaten at Evergreen Garden.  I recall that it was pretty good -- nice patio, tasty pho, but nothing impressive.

Today I had lunch at Evergreen and ordered the "Red Curry Ckecken."  I asked the waitress what "ckecken" was, but I don't think she understood me.  She said, "Chicken."

I thought that it must be either a misprint or a transliterated Vietnamese word.  I was intrigued, so I thought, why not, and ordered the Ckecken.  With shrimp.

Wow!  It was spicy and delicious.  The shrimp were marinated in a sweet and spicy chili paste, and cooked with green beans and chopped red and green bell peppers, served with rice.  And no chicken.

I'll be back next week to eat this dish again.  And maybe I'll ask what exactly "Ckecken" means?

(Incidentally, the service was very good -- friendly and attentive.)
author: Daniel S.

description: I was given a menu that had appetizers on the front page instead of Pho. Then I asked for the another and there was the Pho. I ordered a "#1" from the menu. A big bowl of pho filled with stuff I like, tripe, flank beef, two big beef balls. The portions were pretty big too. Yummy. I liked it a lot. Then again, I can never go wrong with pho. Only problem is that it's located in a suspect neighborhood. Maybe you should drive there at night, but I walked to the place with no problems.
author: Gerard Y.

description: Evergreen Garden is one of those places you pop into for dinner when you can't think of anywhere else to go. Their food is pretty good, their service is pretty good and they are very reasonably priced. For us vegetarians out there, they have a full list of veg options, not just salad rolls and fried tofu like many places. They were very polite and helpful as well. Just know it's a 4 star casual place and you'll be sure to love it!
author: Justus P.

description:
During the day, it's tough to find a parking spot around here, so I was psyched when I found rock star parking right in front after work one night.  Walked inside, and the place smelled so damn good.  The dining area was pretty crowded for a Tuesday at 8.30, but service was quick.  

I read other Yelp reviews before coming here, so I knew that they serve Pho ... it just wasn't listed on the menu.  Underneath the glass covering each table, there are photocopies of pictures of food.  I saw one that must have been the Combo Pho, pointed at it and said "That one ... I want that.  It's pho, right?  The person repeated what I said, so I figured I was safe.

Usually, I stick to Pho with raw beef and flank steak (I'm really into the veggie stuff like sprouts, peppers, lemon/lime, basil, etc) but thought I would live dangerously today since I had to rely on the photo to order and didn't want to deal with the hassle of making a "special" order.

The combo pho had some serious offal in it.  I quake just thinking about it.  I stabbed at one of the beef balls with a chopstick and contemplated eating it, but my broth and beef ball started to resemble a goat scrotum soup that someone had attempted to serve me back in the USSR in 1990, and I just couldn't get my teeth to pierce the membrane and sink into that firm ball of mystery.  

I fished out my beef balls, intestines and tripe and found myself with a small mound of rice noodle in a puddle of watery broth.  The sprouts and veggies as well as the hoisin and sriracha sauce helped liven up the broth, and I drank every last drop.

Next time, I'll take a stab at communicating what I want from the beginning, or I'll just order off the menu like all the other happy people in the restaurant.

Why four stars?  Because it smelled so damn good in there, all the other dishes looked/smelled great, and it was my own stupid fault for not asking to have them hold the scary stuff in my Pho.
author: Jenny K.

description:
It's a cute establishment at the corner of 18th St and Harrison, with wide airy dining area and patio, lots of plants decorating, very oasis-like.
But the food was definitely forgetable.  There was nuthin' INedible, though the #25 chicken thigh in a lemon chili sauce was damn near - you gotta really overcook thigh meat to get it THAT stringy.
Liked the stir fried veggies w/tofu, bok choy and mushrooms(#68?) - garlic-y, and the crunch still evident in the veggies!  
Garlic noodles were ok, too - again, garlic saving the day.
My friend & I chose this place for it's nearness to the Project Artaud Theatre; we figured it'd be fast and cheap and it did deliver on that score. 
Next time you need a quick none-too-wallet-busting bite before a show there, try Evergreen Garden on for size.  Bring mints, though, or you might clear the theatre with your breath.
author: CINDY K.

description: You know what I like about this place?  They're nice!  I love dealing with nice people, and the people at evergreen make it a point to make you feel welcome, even when they are delivering.  The food here is pretty good, but I keep coming back for the service.
author: David C.

description:
The food is pretty standard Vietnamese, but I really like the porch-like "outdoor" seating with all the plants.  The service was a bit absent, but otherwise charming (read: flirtatious).  

Weird hood, but I'm sure it will be gentrified in a few years.
author: Alissa K.

description: I've been a customer for nine years. While the service can be somewhat slow, the Ch giò and ph are delicious and Peter and Wendy (the owners) are lovely hosts.
author: Michael H.

description:
This place was the first place I ever tried Vietnamese food and now I am hooked!

It's kind of a dive but who cares - thats what I like about these kind of places, the little fishtank in the corner, the toy figurines that are pretty gawdy but kind of cute, and the really good food that comes out of the kitchen. Plus, the family who runs the place are so incredibly nice and warm-hearted.  You just know they have a story or two to tell.


I like the #14 and the Imperial rolls the most.  Sucks they aren't open for my Sunday night Togo habit... ;(
author: Yelper A.

description: In the Mission/Potrero Hill/Noe Valley area there aren't many good Vietnamese restaurants around. In fact, there aren't many around (unlike Larkin Street). But thats neither here nor there. The Grilled Pork over rice and Bun Bo Hue are my favorite.  They're fast, they deliver, and they have the right portions for the right prices. Don't expect fine dining or excellent service  and you won't be disappointed. Just expect a good lunch or dinner at a decent price.
author: Vien T.

description:
I go here often after climbing with my pals. It's funky and inexpensive and the waitstaff are unobtrusive and attentive. 

 My recommendation is the spicy eggplant. Delicious!

The garlic noodles at Sunflower are totally different, so don't be expecting the same thing if you've had them there. These were thin noodles with bbq pork and a reddish sauce.
author: Elsa E.

description:
I work in the Mission and hate leaving my parking spot as it can be a giant pain in the ass trying to find another.  So I rely on many delivery services in the area.  Hence, my discovery of Evergreen Garden.

Every time I order from this place my meal always arrives within 20 minutes.  The food has always been impressive.  Really fucking impressive!  I usually stick to the rice plates & pho.  Generous portions and the prices are CHEAP!   

Need I say more?
author: Larry A.

description:
When you walk into Evergreen Garden, you get the feeling that you're walking into grandma's house.  A house that is way too big for your tiny weak grams.  Then, you see all of these people your grandma hired to help her clean and cook around the house.  Well, these helpers aren't doing the best job to help keep the house clean and they certainly don't cook the food the way grandma used to make.  This is the best analogy I could come up with to sum up my experience...  

So, yeah, I felt disappointed because my soup came out super fast but the sprouts were brown at the tips that I didn't even get a chance to have sprouts with my Pho.  I've been eating Pho before that ish came into culinary style so I definitely have had better.  My poor sister had the fried banana with ice cream and that didn't come out for ages (2 scoops of coconut ice cream and a friend bananas taking longer than 15 minutes is quite a long time).  In any case, it took even longer to get the check.  

Yes, grandma's friend's are nice but that doesn't mean they should be in the kitchen cooking...
author: Dorothy S.

description:
These guys are not open on Sundays, so it took me a while to actually try this place.  It looks so cute from the outside, so I was psyched, plus with all the anticipation of trying to go here a few times and forgetting it's weird hours (which are not posted correctly on their door nor on this page).  So I was all set for a fall.

But the place is great.  Great decor, great food, friendly staff.  No problem parking at all.

I didn't smell this chlorine bleach smell that some Yelpers are kvetching about.  Just lemongrass and garlic.  I even smelled the lemongrass etc. when they were closed.  Which is weird, but whatevs.
author: Nessie V.

description: Delivery Pho!!!  This is my go-to delivery place when I'm sick... the soup is perfect!
author: victoria s.

description: Totally charming servers and patio. There WILL be something wrong with whatever you order. Relax. The world is an imperfect place.
author: Zoe B.

description:
5/08 - Crap - i have to down-star them - I'm sooooo bummed - I got food poisoning here TWICE! The first time I thought it was "just me" but the second time - there was no doubt. I can't eat here anymore and I'm soooooo sad!!!! Why 2 stars and not 1 if I got food poisoning? Well, because the food still tastes really good, that's why!

Old review :(
I love this place.  I eat here at least once a week.  I am addicted to "Bun" - #29 specifically.  Sometimes I wonder what is in the food that I wake in the middle of the night sweating and crying out for vermicelli bunnnnnn with deep fried egg roll....  I have tried this dish at numerous other Vietnamese places and though it is good elsewhere, it is bestest here - sez me.

I have, tried their other dishes - when other people have ordered them. Their beef curry was quite good, their Vietnamese omelet was good and their pan fried noodles looked good when I spied someone else eating them.  The cold wrapped shrimp rolls are delish.  

I used to eat here years ago when it was Hung Yen and I loved it then, perhaps a bit more even than I love it now.  When it changed ownership I was disappointed and stopped going for years but now that I'm back, I'm loving it - like I said - enough to eat here weekly and dream about the food.  

The atmosphere is not the greatest, but it's nice to eat outside.  And, it's pretty inexpensive.  #29 comes to $7.10 and lasts me most of the day.  Ohhhhhh darn, I'm craving it again nowwwwwwwwwwwwwww!!!!
author: Kimberly H.

description:
For some bizarre reason there are several different versions of the menu in this place. I never get given the Pho menu to start with, but after asking you're all set for a good feed. 

The might-have-been-a-garage-once-random-kitch interior gives the place a charm only your grandmother's 1970s extension could offer.

I've only ever had the Pho and see no reason to explore further.
author: Gabriel W.

description: I love this place. It is my go to for quick, Vietnamese delivery, which always arrives hot. The portions are huge and their Thai options are also solid. it's also cheap!
author: Samantha S.

description:
We hit this today during Carnival (I know, weird with all the vendors they had).

This place was cheaper than the food at the booths and you could pay on the sidewalk and still sit inside the restaurant.  It was a nice break from walking all around Carnival.

The food was pretty good, not your typical service - as you got it on a paper plate from the sidewalk, but I have no complaints.  It wasn't chaotic at all despite all the people there.

I doubt I would pick this restaurant ahead of time as a dinner destination, but if I'm in the Mission and wanting Viet, I would feel comfortable going back.
author: Jen K.

description:
This place is a nightmare, especially during lunch.

I'll begin by saying that for lunch I always will have a craving for Vietnamese. Evergreen Garden isn't great, but it's food has always satisfied me. Their meat is passable and eggrolls always nicely crunchy.

But their customer service has a lot to be desired. Honestly the staff need to take a customer service class. I want to sit them down and have them learn proper etiquette and basic order taking.

I thought I had learned my lesson, since I've run into problems before, but today I was overcome with the urge for something "vietnamesey" and "crunchy."

So I phoned in an order like I always do: "hello can I take a number 32 with an extra imperial roll?" "sure, sure, ok, thank you, bye bye." (click) Uh it would have helped if you had taken down my name, given me the total, and told me how long it would take without hanging up so quickly...

I walk in and it's a mad house. There is a line of people, and the counter can't accommodate two people since the person on the left will get enveloped with some plant-tree.

Anyways, I forget if I ordered the number 30 or 32, and explain to them it's the beef with vermicelli and an extra order of imperial roll. Easy? No. The little asian lady and man walk around confusingly acting as if they had never taken such an order. I re-explain myself, and they try handing me something with shrimp. Uh, no? It took them another 10 minutes to realize they DID take my order and another 10 to finally get me my order. All the while I was waiting around and taking in the dirty looks they kept throwing at me.

I promised myself I wouldn't give another 1 star review, but their attitude and bad service just can't keep me from glazing it over with two stars or three.

Sorry guys, I'm not going to torture myself, again. (period)
author: Carlo F.

description:
I eat here almost everyday for lunch. Mostly I just get fresh rolls w/ shrimp (#20) or Bun w/ bbq pork and shrimp (#30). I obviously like it :-) The owners are very friendly and always remember my favorites. Today I tried the #46 - Spicy shrimp lemongrass curry. It was great. - glad I ventured out. It's a non-coconut milk curry so it's a little healthier and comes with lots of grilled veggies. My only disappointment was the lack of shrimp. There were only 3 in the whole dish! Anyway, I'll still go back. I have so many things to try still!

**Update - I was still eating when I wrote this - I found all of the shrimp hidden in the bottom!!! Yay!**
author: Natalie G.

description:
I'm basing my review on just 1 dish so it could be flawed. This dish is Lemongrass Chicken (LC), which is the way i judge most Vietnamese restaurants (I travel miles for Le Chevals LC).

They warned it would be hot. It had whole red peppers which once I moved them aside left no hotness to the dish. The sauce seemed to be all oyster sauce. No lemongrass or ginger was evident. The chicken was tough. Overall very salty, tasting like garden variety Chinese food. 

They didn't seem to have a lunch special, so at lunch time this was $7.25 with no soup etc, a tad overpriced to me. Then again they have a captive audience of whoever works nearby!
author: Susie W.

description: The #1 beef noodle soup is very good. It's not very special as I think those pho places tastes similar to me. But it is delicious. I go there every week. They also have a nice atrium.
author: Shaoting C.

description:
YES! Finally, an alternative to my Pho Tan Hoa in the Tenderloin that closes at 7. Usually, I have to scramble to get to Pho Tan Hoa since they close so early, but now, I won't have to worry about that anymore. Evergreen Garden is a perfect substitute for it.

In fact, there are some areas where EG dominates PTH. Their vermicelli noodles and eggrolls are much better. Just like the homemade eggrolls my mom makes. The pho is where I get conflicted. It tastes healthier (maybe less msg), but the portion size isn't as big. Either way, it's still a great steal. For a bowl of pho and a bowl of bun, it comes out to around $17 including tax and tip. There are also a variety of chow mien and other specialty Vietnamese dishes I haven't tried, but smelled, and those seem like they'd be really delicious too.

The BF and I were originally a little weary of this place because of its exterior, but I'm glad we got over that (thanks to yelp). It's close to our gym so it'll definitely be one of those dinner savers I need once or twice a week.
author: Angela L.

description: Good food, good delivery. Food always taste fresh and I never have to wait long for delivery. The imperial rolls can be a little too taro-y, but overall everything is tasty. The chicken and pork in the vermicelli is always tender and well marinated. Papaya salad is great too.
author: Kate S.

description:
I love this place because...

1) it is across from the climbing gym
2) it's never too crowded for a table
3) open late!
4) the food comes almost immediately
4) the waiter always remembers me by name, and knows my order... even when I missed a whole year 'cause I moved to the east bay, and moved back, he still remembered me! I love it!

I almost always get the #1. It's the best Pho I have found in the city. I don't pretend to be any sort of expert, but it's mighty tastier than any other I have tried in SF. I also like #32, for the record. (BBQ pork and imperial rolls)

Yumm.
author: Emily W.

description:
i used to work a block from this place but it was under old ownership.  in the past few years it has undergone a pleasant change.

I get their vermicelli bowls (buon? bun?)  just fresh, well done cuisine.  this is my favorite Vietnamese in the bay area.  love this place. it's solid and consistent.
author: Brandon V.

description:
This place is an additional perk to my new office space.  The food is consistently good, cheap, fast and the people that run it are very nice.

I love that they don't close between lunch and dinner and I can come in (for take-out or eat in) anytime of day and get food for those few minutes I can pull myself away from the computer and work phone.
author: Johanna w.

description:
#1 on the menu. So good. This place has become a tradition with my friends and I. I haven't had a disappointing time here. I love the outdoor seating on a sunny day. The staff are all super friendly and the good is all really good! I recommend going here.

Don't forget to grab a fortune cookie when you leave as well.
author: Clive H.

description:
This is my go-to spot whenever I'm just hungry and not sure where to go.  Seem like most folks are here for the pho...BUT whoa there's a lot more on the menu.  FYI - I've never had the pho here...

Things that I order w/o opening the menu - the catfish sweet, spicy, sour soup (oooh amazing in winter and during those rainy SF days), imperial rolls (they don't make it anywhere else like that...besides Mayflower in Chinatown --- wait they used to own that place!), lemon/raw beef (just delish and flavorful), mungbean crepe (lots of shrimp and you can taste that sweet mungbean in the crepe), fried shrimp, and fried banana w/ ice-cream (it's not tempura fried banana, but wrapped like an eggroll!)

That's more than enough for any meal, and the price is sooo cheap!  I've even had my birthday here before w/ 20 people.  LOVE =)
author: Judy C.

description:
Didn't this place used to be called Evergreen Terrace? Either my memory is failing me or my memory has been so saturated from watching 3 syndicated episodes of the simpsons everyday for YEARS. 

I used to eat here fairly often...the quality was hit or miss. Some of the curry dishes were of the generic thick yellow variety that looked like the skin color of the Simpsons. Ack...I swear...that TV show applies to everything. The bun was ok; not as good as Tu Lan, but not bad either. The pork was good...but when is pork not good?

The food is decent...it's for eaters not diners people! But the restaurant itself is rather particular and odd, like a vietnamese couple took over a restaurant in some podunk rest stop off the 5, then transported it to Harrison street, plopped it down, then lofts like weeds sprouted all around.
author: Leslie Ann R.

description:
Evergreen, these four stars are not necessarily for your food or your service or the decor.  You're fairly inconsistent with the quality of your food but you somehow seem to teeter above the line of acceptability.  Your service is horrible when you're busy - the food is incorrect, some dishes are quick and some are slow to arrive, you never pay us any attention let alone bring the check when we're done!  And the decor...those knick knacks that line every centimeter of the window sill need to go!  Embrace the concept of minimalism and clear it out.

HOWEVER, you know I love you because I just had dinner with you, I have frequent lunches with you, and I've even catered our office board meetings with you - twice!  I've had the opportunity to get to know many people on your staff and in your family.  Everyone is warm and friendly and you always ask about me when my colleagues dine without me - which makes me feel loved :)  The variety you have on the menu is to be commended (though you could take out the Thai section and leave that to the Thais.) - I especially love your catfish claypot and sour soup, a combination that always makes me think of my mom.  So, thank you.

I want you to succeed and thrive in this city full of loveless restaurants.  Best of luck to you!  I will continue to come back and I hope to change my rating to five stars someday.
author: Nicole N.

description: Pho, good. MSG very bad. I mean, I'm not philosophically against it, but it makes my head tight, not the desired result from otherwise very TASTY and fresh pho. Is it in the broth? I suppose so. Bummer.
author: Bowen D.

description: Pretty good for lunch and much better for dinner. Sometimes the meat doesn't seem absolutely fresh at lunch service. So I prefer to only go for dinner. Although the won ton noodle soups are great if you are sick and need to punch out a cold.
author: Kathryn G.

description: first Id like to say that this place has honest people that is why I gave it three stars. The food on the other hand is not the best. I went here twice now and don't get me wrong its ok but hats the problem its just ok. I ordered the #1 and spring rolls. When the spring rolls came out they were dry and tasted bland and the peanut sauce was very watery and also not flavorful as it should be. The pho came out with a bunch of cilantro on top which I didn't like. It would have been nice to know that they toped it with that I would have opted out. Overall my first visit was ok there wasn't a lot of people maybe two other tables were occupied. The second time I came their with my friend. The service wasn't the best and we didn't even get water until flagging the lady down and when they brought the water out...5 min later they gave my water to the wrong table. I order the pho and spring rolls again hoping this time It will taste better. This time I opted out of cilantro. The spring rolls came out and they tasted horrible. My friend and I bit into it and then stopped eating it. They tasted like they were frozen or made 2 days before. Very dry and bland. The sauce was watery again as well. The pho came out and it was bland nothing special deff not worth the 7 or 8 bucks I paid. When it was time to pay the bill they didn't take the spring rolls off our bill even though we told them they were bad. We paid the bill and left but to my surprise I left my phone their. I realized this at around 11 pm when they were already closed. The next day I cam and the older man had it and gave it back. I love the honesty of the workers their. I believe this was the owner who gave me back my phone but it doesn't matter. Everyone is nice I say try this place out.
author: Nelly L.

description:
This place deserves a spot in the regular lunch rotation.

I like the pho (#7 Tai Nam); the broth doesn't taste super-laden with MSG (if there's any at all; there seems to be a conflict of opinion here).

I'm not as much into the rice plates here. It is all white steamed rice; I prefer the yellow BBQ rice.
author: Rob T.

description:
MSG & Pubic hair (yes between crotch)

great tasting at first.  if you want to taste true flavor of MSG...this is the place.  

untalented cook will do two things...took lots and lots of MSG to make it super salty...

for those who does not know the taste of MSG...when order ask to be cook w/ msg...you will see the difference.  this doesn't apply to bbq stuff...been marinated and can't get the MSG out.

issue on the hair...

i tried pho 4 times...my co workers are living witness...
in SF restaurants at this level... cockroaches and eye lashes don't bother me much...once day...four hair follicles all tangled with meat...i know when i see a pubic hair...

i showed it to the counter lady...she said it's from meat suppliers...

they are super nice people...but very forgetful with hot sauces, giving wrong food on take out & only to find out later , missing utensils....being super nice and apologetic only can go so far...

no place to go eat...try once...but MSG & Pubic hair...No Thanks!!

2 star because they are super nice people rather than just ONE star
author: B K.

description: Yummy food.  Good prices.  A great lunch spot.  Friendly service.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Eh...whatevs. The food is edible but not much better quality than at a cafeteria. The Imperial rolls were crispy and the filling was well seasoned. The rice is cooked adequately by the rice cooker. The pork chop was well seasoned, not particularly tender nor tough, and had a boring grayish color. The pho is ok, but a far cry from that tower place in the tenderloin. The beef broth wasn't particularly flavorful or soothing. Yea...this review is a snoozer, but so is the food. Zzzzzzz
author: Siao W.

description:
UPDATED: 3/7/08

I've been here several times already and still love the food and the service here.  The pho is comforting and their Chia Gao (fried imperial rolls) are awesome.  However, the much anticipated Bun Bo Hue was disappointingly unauthentic.  No thick vermicelli noodles, and none of the crazy animal parts this dish is supposed to have.  But considering this place is located in the Mission (read: mostly non-Asian clientele), I understand...

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

An insider told me that the old owners of Golden Flower Vietnamese Restaurant in Chinatown (which was soooo much better when run by the old owners) took over Evergreen Garden.  The SO and I tried this out last night, after deciding we didn't want to drive all the way to Chinatown and go around the block 10 times to find parking.  There's ample parking, and we've decided we'd come here for pho over Chinatown any day.

We started off with the Banh Xeo (crepe) and ordered a bowl of pho for each of us.  The crepe was huuuuge.  The garnishes were very fresh, unlike many Vietnamese places where the bean sprouts normally come out with a brownish hue, an indicator that they've been sitting out too long.  We enjoyed the crepe a lot, and loved the fact that they didn't come rushing out with our noodles.  We really got to enjoy it.  The pho was pretty good as well, however I noticed the broth wasn't as clear as it used to be at Golden Flower.  The portions are huge, we were stuffed.  I noticed that they have Bun Bo Hue on their menu, I can't wait to try it next time!

Service is good, food is yummy, I'd definitely come back here again.  The restaurant seems out of the place in this outer Mission area, and the decor made us feel like we were having Vietnamese food in Jamaica, but it fit and we liked it a lot.  My only gripe is the really really dim bathroom lights, it seriously didn't feel like there was even a light on!
author: Diane L.

description:
Right near my work and quite satisfying for a quick and cheap lunch. Probably wouldn't go out of my way to eat it, but not bad at all.

Today, I ordered a chicken soup from them as a cold remedy. The broth, lemon, and jalapenos made me feel much better, mmm.

I also love the big flat egg noodles they have here. Delicious.
author: Laura B.

description:
The pho's pretty good, but the bun thit nuong chia gio (grilled pork over vermicelli w/imperial egg rolls) is *ridiculous* good.  

And big ups for DELIVERY.  (Minimum $20, but the day I ordered for the office, that was no problem.)  We also like to do the occasional lunch outing here when we can break out of the cubicles for more than an hour.

Cheap, fast, and tasty -  that's how I likes it!
author: M. H.

description:
When this place was called Hung Yen several years ago, it was truly impressive, especially their vegetarian dishes.  But then the family that ran it sold it to the current owners.  The world is a dimmer place as a result.

It's not that the food is bad at all.  There's just nothing in particular to recommend it.  I've been there four or five times, but it's just not on my list of must-do restaurants, and I certainly wouldn't bring an out of town visitor here as an example of fine Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Paul B.

description:
I go rock climbing at Mission Cliffs across the street, so I popped in here one afternoon when I had worked up an appetite.

It's pretty decent Vietnamese food.  Nothing spectacular, but good quality overall.  Portions are big, they have plenty of space, and offer both indoor and quasi-outdoor (enclosed patio) seating.

I'd recommend it if you happen to be in the area and you're hungry.
author: Dave C.

description:
I eat here all of the time and is the best Vietnamese restaurant outside of Richmond and Irving St. in the Sunset.  Pho is on par with other Pho restaurants but the excel in the other vietnamese dishes such as Lemon Raw Beef, catfish in claypot, and their soups....They don't carry your standard Vietnamese desserts nor fruit drinks...not a big deal but be forewarned.

As others have mentioned, there is an outdoor eating place but I don't find it anything special.

It is a very casual restaurant, service a bit slower, but the food is well-prepared and authentic.  The thai dishes are below average and not recommended.
author: Laurence H.

description: Great place for lunch!  I've been there dozens of times, and especially love the cold spring rolls and the bbq pork chops over rice.  Delicious! You can eat on their sunny patio if it's nice out, or inside if it's not.  Sweet older man server can't be beat either.
author: marika b.

description:
This place is right in my neighborhood - it's a great casual place for good food at reasonable prices.  The service is excellent - very attentive and friendly staff.

My fav's are the Bun Cha Gio Thit....(Bun Vermicelli).  I also tried the Five Spice Chicken a few weeks back - very tasty and yummy.
author: Gina C.

description:
God, this place is pretty forgettable. 
They don't even have the dish I can get at basically any other VN restaurant, beef stew ho fun. What the hell? 
And the last time I was there, which will probably be the last time for a very long time, I literally did not get a freakin bowl of noodles until 45 minutes after entering the place. For real. 
I would probably go back if I needed some forgettable Asian food and it was not the peak of lunch hour. And if every other restaurant around were closed. That's about it. I'd much rather go to Tu Lan or almost anywhere else in the TL.
author: Thlel Yan D.

description:
Despite of all not-so-great reviews, I still like Evergreen Garden.

1. I NEVER had to wait to be seated (maybe there's a reason why....)
2. PLENTY of street parking
3. They DELIVER!
4. I like their chicken salad
5. Super FAST serving (just like majority of Vietnamese restaurants when you order pho)
6. Option of Thai and Vietnamese menu (kinda strange)

Unfortunately, I often crave Evergreen food on Sundays when they are closed!
author: Yoko S.

description: Didn't have pho and what we had was decent but not great.  Based on other reviews, you probably should have the pho. The place is also fairly dirty & dated but that's often the case with hole in the walls so can't hold that against them. The service was super slow; servers refuse to make eye contact and are usually in the back we basically had to beg for the check to get out of there so -1 star for the service.
author: Trishan A.

description: Ehh.  I'm pretty unenthused about this place.  It was close by to where I live, and thought I would get some noodles for takeout.  Cheap, great.  Closeby, awesome.  Ambiance, cute, albeit a bit kitchy.  However, got seafood noodle soup (enough for two), and it made me and my friend sick.  It was NOT great.  Neither the sick or the food.  The seafood tasted like immitation crab and other random unidentifiable weirdness...I suppose when trying out a new place you should always stick to chicken, hard to mess that up.  Either way, the place seemed alright, but the fact that it took them 10 minutes more than what they told me I would have to wait, and the fact that it made my friend and me sick...well, two stars for effort, ey?
author: Courtney H.

description: The first pho I have ever tried, and a year later still the best.
author: Gene R.

description: This place is great for what it is - an extremely moderately priced delivery place. The delivery is fast, friendly, and the remember the extras we want without us even asking.  I think they even got vanilla ice cream just because I kept asking for it.  The food is solid - the soups and stir fries have tons of fresh veggies. The chow mein is wonderful.  The pho is decent, the vegetable and bean curd soup is one of my favorite ways to get my vegetables, especially when ordering delivery.
author: Laura F.

description:
This place changed hands while I worked less than a block away. I'm not sure it went down in quality or that the change was unwelcomed, but the establishment leaves a lot to wish for. It is a very interesting building and has something of an outdoor garden eating area. I remember I thought I'd bring a friend here. We decided to sit outside at first. On that particular lunch hour the establishment thought it would be a good idea to get some construction done and started cutting some metal with an electronic saw. To make this short, there is really no quite way of cutting metal with a saw. They stopped sawing after we pointed out that we could barely hear the hammering over the loud scrapping and motor noise of the saw. 

The food is ok. There was one bad day where the meal I got made me never want to eat vietnamese food again, but given the small choice of lunch spots in the area, I came back. They have a pretty good vegetarian menu and the spring rolls are tasty, if the sauce is made right that day. I swear the spring roll was going to spring back up from my stomach one particularly bad sauce making day.

You may ask why I keep going back or why I gave it three stars. I guess I don't know many vietnamese places or what I should expect from them. I give them the benefit of the doubt. I don't work in the area anymore, but happened to be in a bar nearby the other night and ate there for dinner. It is definitely not a place I would go to unless it was extremely convenient, which when drunk and hungry, I had no other choice except mexican.
author: Alex L.

description:
Why is this place nicknamed the car wash?  

Ok food.  Good prices.  Nothing special, but nothing bad.
author: Matt V.

description:
After our Best buy ran in the Mission.

I had cravings of either some Mexican food or Vietnamese soups. Taqueria was closed on Saturday that we ended up at Evergreen Garden Restaurant.

At first glance, I kinda like the little garden that they have in place. Once you walked inside it looks like 2 little house combined. Like a Mom & Pop place.  I

Pho was good & tried their Vienames 33 beer (very light) I might say. Pretty descent restaurant, good pho and cheap price.
author: jubi l.

description:
great basic Vietnamese food at very reasonable prices. The Pho and Bun noodle dishes as well as Imprerial and spring rolls are yum.  Your best basic Vietnamese restaurant in the mission area.

And the wait staff and owners are sooo sweet. They make you feel right at home.
author: Sanaz E.

description:
First time write a review on-line.

This place has come from OK to terrible. Ordered two dishes today: one catfish clay pot, one chow fun.

Catfish costs $9. What we got was 5 pieces fishes in soy sauce.
Chow fun costs $8+ Terrible, covered with all kind of burn particle. Maybe they didn't clean the pot before making the dish. All we can taste was burning smell.
Rice costs $1.5: one bowl

Total lunch for two: $20+

Plenty of restaurants nearby, 5-10mins walking distant offer much better food with more reasonable price.
author: lei z.

description: Great hole-in-the-wall, good prices. Stand-outs on menu include any Pho or Bun dish. Usually no wait for a table.
author: Bradley H.

description:
Good luck finding a parking spot, but once you do, take a seat in the faux outdoor seating side (left side) where it feels like you get to enjoy the sun. Pretty standard selection of Vietnamese food. The place could be cleaner.

Service is very very slow. If you go, make sure you're not in a rush.

The food is quite tasty. The Bun Bo Hui (vermicelli in spicy beef and tomato broth) is flavored with coconut and lemongrass. The broth is amazing, but the vermicelli is cheap and doesnt do the broth justice. The Pho noodles are pretty standard, but again their broth is amazing.

This place has the potential to be really great if they used fresher and unique noodles.
author: benjamin c.

description:
Pretty solid Vietnamese food located in a place other than the 'Loin. I'm picky with my Pho, so i've never tried it here, but I have tried the vermicelli dishes, the catfish in a clay pot, and the banh xeo (crispy crepe). All were pretty good. 

Nothing mind blowing here, but a place you can rely on when in the mood for typical Vietnamese fast food. And they deliver, which is awesome.
author: Sabine S.

description: Fast, tasty and not expensive. I think I like Sunflower more. But the pho, unlike Sunflower, is more authentic here. Vermecelli bowls are good, but the quantity could me more. Good cheap eats that always hits the spot during my office lunch.
author: Anish B.

description: One of my favorite lunch places...their food is great, and I have tried almost everything on the menu. Plus, their service is really good...it's a family run place and they are genuinely happy to have your business. I love Evergreen!
author: Julia M.

description: outdoor patio....deep fried eggrolls.  This place isn't fancy, but it sure is yummy.
author: Darren M.

description: My softball team has eaten here several times after practice because we play in the area and it's pretty convenient.  I think the food here is pretty standard Vietnamese fare and it's done pretty well.  I usually order the vermicelli with bbq pork and imperial rolls and its never disappointed me.  I also like the chicken and cabbage salad here.  My friends have also gotten pho and seafood noodle soup.  The service is friendly and responsive and the prices are reasonable.  They also have a large vegetarian selection.
author: Tyler C.

description: The vermicelli was very refreshing comes with diversity of veggies with BBQ meat of your choice. The BBQ chicken is well sauteed and grilled just right. The pho isn't special but its outdoor dining is relaxing. The customer service is outstanding. I chat with the owner everytime we are there.
author: Chase L.

description: I really enjoy ordering from this restaurant.  Service is very polite and food is very good!  Love #1 soup and #16 Spicy Basil and chicken over rice!
author: D A.

description: We're vegetarian and this place is legit for vietnamese food that can still be vegetarian. It's a hole in the wall, but the food is authentically spiced, the dishes available are much more diverse than your typical vietnamese restaurant, and the taste of the food is nearly the best I've had in the Bay Area. A gem.
author: Jason M.

description:
I'm not much of a pho eater or even this genre of food in general. This place is a few buildings down from us and we've been frequenting this place for large take-out orders for meetings as well as lunch. Its a great place. 

The dishes we enjoy the most are Crispy Shrimp Rolls (104), Shrimp Rolls (20) and Red Curry Ckecken (chicken) (116).

I've also had their veggie Pho (100). I confirmed it is veggie broth and it was fantastic. Simple mix of veggies: broccoli, carrots, scallions, celery, bok choi and mushrooms with a broth that tasted too good to be veggie. Comes with rice noodles too, but I ordered it without.

The Red Curry Chicken is what we tried first when we first came here and it is one of the reasons for the 5 star. Its awesome. We usually ask for extra sauce with it.
author: Karsten M.

description:
Cold rainy day. Takeout Pho after a long run in the rain. 

Awesome Pho! Chicken is fresh and very lean, broth is rich but not greasy at all. They set you up with ample fresh basil and sprouts (forgot the japalenos, though) and plenty of meat and noodles. 

Finally -- a good neighborhood Pho spot.

WHOA: Newsflash!!!! DO they use MSG? Don't know, did taste salty, but two hours post consumption = head throbbing and major stomach trouble.
author: Caitlin S.

description: This seems to be my work food spot...can't blame them.  Food is good, there's a patio & service is quick.  Their fried rolls are the best!  Everything here is good, so you can never go wrong.
author: Jo B.

description: Stopped by for lunch today from a friend's recommendation. We were in the neighborhood for a big warehouse sale so didn't have any idea where to go for lunch. Was really close by and easy to find parking. We got the chicken pho and the vegetarian crepe. Both had great flavor and was really tasty. The pho noodles kind of stuck together, probably from being prepared way in advanced but it was still good. Service was quick except for bringing out our beverages, since the waitress forgot. I'm not sure when I'd come back since I hardly go out that way but I'm sure it's a place I'd frequent for a Vietnamese fix.
author: Mochi L.

description: Great spicy PHO!  We have had some of the other dishes there which were great also.  We usually go about once a week and the food is always consistent.  Service is friendly and always seem happy to see you.  Parking is available on the street and I have never had a problem finding a spot.
author: Kim K.

description: I came here for lunch with a friend a few months ago and ate the nastiest meal of my life. We ordered the catfish dish, which cost about $10 and all we got were 3 measly pieces of catfish which were overcooked and soaked in soy sauce. The fish was dry and had an unpleasant earthy taste and smell. We also ordered a seafood chow fun, which was equally nasty and distasteful. The dish had bits and pieces of burnt particles in it which was likely the residue of a dirty pan they didn't bother to wash. In addition, the noodles were dry and all clumped together. The experience thoroughly disgusted my friend and I and we vowed never to return here again. There are plenty of affordable, delicious options in this area. The shitty food we unfortunately ingested at this place made McDonald's look like a high-end restaurant.
author: Renée J.

description: Nice affordable restaurant. Lots of cute trendy people hanging out with bikes. I ordered the mango salad with shrimps and loved it and the seafood pho. Tasty broth and lots of stuff to eat in the soup. I also tried the salty plum drink and it was good although I think it's an acquired taste and many people probably wouldn't like it but I'm used to eating tamarind in my foods so I'm pretty used to the flavor. It's nice to be able to try different things and I would come back to this restaurant. Friendly staff.
author: Racheljoy R.

description:
Two weeks after beating back a cold, here I am again, searching the Mission for pho. I'm not very happy about this. No doubt the work travels this week and general lacked of sleep helped make this happen, but come on, I was popping Airborne and zinc left and right and thought I'd emerge unscratched. Not so much.

Which brings me to Evergreen Garden, a random Vietnamese spot at 18th/Harrison. The neon pho sign illuminated my destination as I got closer, and I was anxious for what other yelpers had said was good, cheap pho.

And that is exactly what I got. Not too heavy, very inexpensive ($6.50) and done up really quick. They even take credit cards.

Next time I need a pho fix, and venturing to a new spot is out of the question, I'd definitely return. Fifth star reserved for if I miraculously wake up tomorrow cured.
author: Jason B.

description: Had the Pho with co-workers. Couldn't sit outside because it was rented out, but that they have an inside/outside patio is bonus.
author: K. C.

description: I have been to 4 vietnamese restaurants in the city so far... and I have still not found a place that makes better or the same level of pho than in Los Angeles.  I always get the Pho Dac Biet where ever I eat pho because it has the variety of stuff in it like meatballs, eye roundsteak, flank, tendon, brisket and tripe.   This place does a decent job... and the broth is missing something...  Oh the service isnt that great here... ive had to ask one of the ladies 3 times for coke... hmm.. maybe i should be giving this place 2 stars rather than 3...
author: Jasen L.

description: This is my PHo Spot and the Fresh Spring rolls are crazy good..
author: Alberto D.

description: The Pho is decent and the location convenient.  The decor is a bit outdated and needs a fresh coat of paint.  but the food is decent!
author: A P.

description: I like the place (nice patio when it's sunny) and the food is really good. I'm a big fan of pho soup and even if it's not the best I had, it's pretty ok.
author: David F.

description: This spot is a little out of the way, and that's what I love about it. When the Mission gets overwhelmed on the weekends by bridge & tunnel jag-offs, and I need to eat dinner, Evergreen Garden does the trick with cheap, tasty Vietnamese food at an intimate setting.
author: Paul J.

description:
Had lunch there today for the first time with a friend..  Never had Vietnamese food before.  Had the shimp egg rolls (they're cold) with a dipping sauce, cashew chicken and chicken chow mein. 2 cokes.   Everything delicious, very good service...$30 bucks with tip
We'll be back...a lot.
author: bert k.

description:
Yesterday I ate half a chicken, well actually I ate something probably predominately soy-ish shaped like half a chicken. I've officially been vegetarian since 6th grade, I say "officially" because by not really liking meat I was probably a default veg. for a while beforehand. As such, I've never been much on a quest for food that looks or tastes like meat. But, as I have had my fill of stir-fried tofu dishes at least until my 30th birthday, during my most recent trip to Evergreen Garden I had the Curry "Chicken" with broccoli. And what I was presented with looked VERY much like a bilaterally dissected chicken, I'm talking including the shape of it's little chicken thigh, with chicken skin (not kidding, it even had the variations of color chicken skin gets when it's cooked and a slightly bumpy texture on its simulated chicken tummy). When I cut into it, I half expected to cut into fake chicken bones. And I'm no chicken expert but the "meat" shredded similarly to chicken. The amazing part? I liked it. A very flavorful, not overly spicy, curry with onions, carrots, and broccoli, this was quite a pleasant tasting meal. Except that I'm still a little freaked out, I think for the same reason that people write science fiction novels about robots taking over civilization. I mean, there's such a thing as too close to the real thing. I don't know, what if this fake chicken decided to give me fake salmonella?
